content: A Hitchcock classic from 1963 featuring Tippi Hedren as Melanie Daniels who goes to Bodega Bay to surprise Rod Taylor's Mitch Brenner with a gift for his young sister. Almost at the same time as arriving flocks of birds begin attacking the townsfolk with deathly consequences.Based very loosely on a Daphne du Maurier story by the same name (Hitchcock has used her material before), and also based on a real, but strange, incident in Monterey Bay (1961) where birds frenzied after eating toxic substances. The film shows the start of the attacks and how those affected cope with it and try to survive. The acting is great much like you'd expect from a Hitchcock film and the script allows them to come across as authentic and believable - albeit Melanie comes across as a bit of a stalker at the start of the film the way she hunts and follows Mitch. The cinematography is superb although there is a lot of studio filmed footage in the film which is noticeable by today's standards - this however doesn't detract from the film. Being the master of suspense Hitchcock decided to leave the films ending open to interpretation although 40+ years later people are still debating why the birds began attacking in the first place. Is Melanie's arrival with the caged love birds a catalyst? Is it a revenge for the treatment of birds in real life (as mentioned at various points in the film)? Is it (as mentioned a few times) the end of the world slowly unfolding? Whatever the reason behind it audiences who watch this today will be as baffled as audiences who watched this in the 60's. As a standalone film this is great, by today's standards of quality you may be disappointed by the CGI and fake blood, maybe even the naivety of some of the townsfolk too. If you forget those things and sit and watch the film for what it is you'll surely enjoy it.I'm giving this 8 out 10. Having studied Hitchcock at college it still gives me a wry smile thinking about how he pitched to sell this to studio executive as a profitable venture. :)

title: One of Hitch's Best
content: Alfred Hitchcock's favourite movie, The Birds is freaky, intruiging, and great. You can tell The Master liked it because in the movies he liked he put a cameo at the begining so that audiences wouldn't be distracted from the plot trying to find him (examples:Psycho, North by Northwest, Frenzy)It' at the very beggining, walking some dogs out of the pet shop (a fact is they were actually his own). It isn't actually scary until the middle, though there's a bit of gore. But then it gets really freaky! The end is a dissapointment, though. Rated PG-13 for violence, gore, and frightening content.

title: A thrilling film.
content: Birds is a good and very different film for his purpose, but it fails a lot in very basic levels to be considered a great one. Some special effects are super-outdated, honestly it's very awful if compared to nowadays standards(which is obvious). But is obviously as well that i can't blame a film made in 1963 by having bad visual effects. I would be a jerk if i do such thing. Anyways, it's laughably bad. The major problems that i find in this movie are all located in the second half. Some pointless and incomprehensible actions by the characters really annoyed me. Troubles variated since bad editing to mediocre acting. Some of these problems really disappointed me, because i was sure that this movie was going to be great, due to a excellent first hour. But with such big flaws, it can't be considered nothing more than a good film. Shame. But despite some awful and bad planed/executed sequences, the film as a whole it's not so bad in that quest. I was quite satisfied with the birds 'motivations' to the attacks, for example. Also, the great character development is fundamental to the film 'finale' effect, and the dialogues are also very good. To finish, If i had to make a balance, the first half would be a 9.5 and the second half would be something around 5 or 6. Overall, a 7.7/10 is enough.

title: One of Hitchcock's strongest films
content: "The Birds" is one of the greatest classics in Alfred Hitchcock's career. Its story basically reports an attack of raging birds against a small village on the Californian coast. The movie has often been touted as overrated but I definitely disagree. It's true that this kind of situation is quite unusual and the reasons for the abnormal behavior of the birds is never properly explained to us. I also considered the way the main character behaves, practically chasing a man she is attracted to without knowing him, is illogical and, at least, strange. That's the biggest negative criticism I can make of this movie which, apart from that, is flawless. The script explores a "nature vs. human" situation quite well, doing it in a way that we actually see as threatening, dangerous and tense. The way the birds behave is highly intimidating, and I just hope no animal has been wounded during the shootings. Cinematography is very good as well as visual effects. Tippi Hedren gave life to the main character, Melanie Daniels, a young spoiled daughter of a big-shot, and Rod Taylor played Mitch Brenner, for whom she is romantically interested. Both actors went very well in their characters, counting on the collaboration of a very competent support cast.

title: The only good bird is a roasted bird
content: I watched this on TV as a child and, although I forgot all the details a long time ago, it remained carved in my memory as terrifying. Of course, this memory was greatly influenced by its reputation as one of the most famous horrors of all time. I just watched it for the first time as an adult in its entirety and I must say - wtf?! The story is linear, simple and does not require even the slightest use of the brain. It starts as a typical romantic comedy of its time (and it would be better if it stayed that way to the end), and then turns into something that is supposed to be a horror, but it is at best a mediocre drama. There is no mystery and tension that we expect from Hitchcock, there are no interesting dialogues, and performances of the actors are at a rather low level. From today's perspective, the effects are tragicomic, and I believe they were not anywhere near top-notch even for their time, which leads to the question how the hell was this film nominated for an Oscar in that category. Occasionally, the effects were so ridiculous that I had the impression that someone deliberately mocked with bird attacks. This is a film from 1963, not from 1923. The events in the movie remain completely unexplained, but that didn't bother me much because I couldn't care less about the reasons for bird attacks. The only good thing about this movie is the premise itself, because it is relatively realistic. Considering the number of birds on the planet in relation to the number of people, the very idea that birds can turn against us and attack us all at once is horrifying, because, despite their primitiveness in relation to human technology, I believe that in this war mankind would have no chance to win. Ever since I can remember I felt moderate repulsion and disgust towards birds, and after this movie, however unconvincing it may be, I could easily develop a phobia. If this movie was of a more recent date, I would rate it even lower, but, considering technical capabilities of the sixties, I have to give it a slack, so I'll rate it5/10

title: Winging A Cold War Apocalypse
content: Little known to most filmgoers was a traumatic experience that befell Hitch as a young boy, he was accidentally locked in a stairwell that had in it several badly decomposed bird carcasses, where he was forced to remain amidst the stench for hours one afternoon and evening until finally detected and freed.  While Hitch counted the experience as notable but not significant in his childhood development, he did acknowledge it as a partial wellspring in inspiring 'The Birds'. The other major contributing factor was linked to his well known fear of the police.  After completing 'North By Northwest', Hitch was invited by an associate to a social gathering of former policemen who had entered the intelligence profession, and their straightforward discussions of prospects for nuclear apocalypse apparently jarred Hitch to a level of discomfort that he felt the need to take on the apocalyptic dimension of life in the Cold War in a metaphorical manner.  As the concept was being fleshed out, the idea came to Hitch of using the birds as a representative vehicle for life out of balance, and the rest is as they say, history.  Just imagine, if these criteria had applied to the inspiration for "The Sound of Music", what a different film that would have been.....

title: When Birds go Wild!!!
content: The Birds is a Hitchcock classic but I never understood why the birds attacked people in the first place. After all, they can go anywhere thanks to their flying capabilities. Tippi Hedren plays the female who travels to a small Northern California town from San Francisco to deliver love birds to a young girl played by Veronica Cartwright who becomes a great actress as an adult as she was a child. My biggest complaint is why the birds go mad in the first place. I admire Hitchcock for all his genius but I never get an answer and it's still an enjoyable movie. Maybe we just have to figure it out for ourselves or maybe we should stop abusing our habitat. The supporting cast includes Morgan Brittany, Darlene Conley, and Suzanne Pleshette as a school teacher.

title: Hitchcock At His Best
content: Hitchcock at his best. This film, has you on the edge of your seat from start to finish. Although now 40 years old, it is still a film that everyone should see. Tippi Hedren puts in a superb performance. With an excellent supporting cast of Jessica Tandy (Driving Miss Daisy), Rod Taylor and Suzanne Pleshette.

title: There are lots of good parts but
content: Womans. They are like helpless people that cant do anything on their own. I got so frustrated by their random hand and face gestures while getting attacked. They are like dull creatures that cant do anything on their own. Everyone waiting for the "guy". That was pretty annoying to watch. Yes for its time that was the view most of the time but that cant change my view on the bad writing or bad acting. Still I like what I saw and enjoyed it. Probably would rated it much more if I saw it when it came out.

title: Suspense through something you never thought could be scary
content: Who would think birds can be presented as scary? I knew that they would be attacking before I saw this film, but I never thought I could be frightened by them. Well, Hitchcock makes it happen. He has closeups of birds doing things to people that you would never imagine being possible to do without computers. The beauty of the film isn't the birds, although they put films like Deep Blue Sea that are plastered with effects, to shame. The beauty is the suspense. Hitchcock knows all the tricks to scare an audience. Put them in a small room with no way out because the exits have all been boarded up. Then have the real terror begin. Everyone says he is a genious, but this film proves it more than any other. Sometimes I watch movies of his like Saboteur and say "What's so great about Hitchcock?" After seeing The Birds, the answer is almost impossible not to see. His timing, music, and ways of framing scenes so that they are completely frightening. If you want a scary movie, don't see the Haunting or the House on Haunted Hill (new versions), see this movie right here. You may not think birds can be scary but after you see it you won't believe how wrong you were.

title: 7.7/10. Recommended
content: I started my Hitchcock journey recently, i have no words to describe his genius. For reference, my ratings are:NOTORIOUS 9/10VERTIGO 8,9/10.ROPE: 8,2/10.DIAL M FOR MURDER: 8,6/10.THE 39 STEPS : 7,3/10.REAR WINDOW : 8,4/10.I would like to see producers' faces when Hitchcock told them, hey, i've got a wonderful idea, in my next movie seaguls will be the villains, killing people for fun. Are you with me?!This definitely hasn't aged as well as other movies of his. Not gonna lie, some scenes are unintentionally hilarious, i mean, these are freaking seagulls, i couldn't take it seriously at first. However, as the movie progressed, threat became more real. It seems unbelieavable but the final 20-30 minutes are indeed nail-biting. And what about the final shot? A true gothic masterpiece. A picture that i would gladly framed and put it my room as poster.Taylor and Hedren are amazing. First part is like a comedy romance and i liked it a lot. Then all hell breaks loose and i liked it even better. This is undeniably a very good movie. Not a classic Hitchcock movie for sure but i love the fact it is daring. He took a great risk with this plot. And he succeeded once more.

title: The scariest film ever, for many reasons
content: I've seen The Exorcist, The Shining Etc. Yes I admit they have all scared me but nothing, and I mean nothing scared me quit like this movie. The birds is one of kind terror , using less blood then most horror film and no music, and so subtle it just lets your heart beat, maybe a bit too much attacks but still, the film which in the book the art of Alfred Hitchcock says it is a film is a film on abandonment because when ever someone mentions something about being abandoned the birds attack. This film is a one of a kind terror hats off for Hitchcock. Write to me if you disagree, but I hope you won't. This film should be an inspiration to many horror films I hope, then Films these days will be much scarier then they are now.

title: More Hitchcock greatness
content: "The Birds" does a slow boil for the first hour or so. After that, hold on to your hat. The second half is edge-of-your-seat stuff. Director Alfred Hitchcock hit another home run with this movie. "The Birds" hasn't aged a bit. It's a great looking movie with a rock solid cast. I've seen this movie a bunch of times and keeps getting better every time I watch it. My 18 year old daughter had a lot of fun watching this with me the other night. Now maybe I can get her to watch some more of Hitchcock's films. Once you get a taste for Hitchcock there's no turning back. "The Birds" is a true classic.

title: If Dullness is What You Seek...
content: I love Hitch but, for the life of me, why is this movie considered one of his best?In its best moments it's dull. In its worst moments it's slightly duller without a jot or iota of suspense. I mean, really, many scenes attempted to build suspense but the construction proceeded at the pace of a snail on downers and the "payoff" never got funded.Great director, good to great actors, awful and boring film.

title: Eery and Satisfying Hitchcock Film
content: The film starts out interestingly enough with Mitch Brenner checking out Annie Hayworth in a bird store, claiming he would like to purchase a pair of love birds. Annie and Mitch end up knowing each other from a some sort of court dispute. Mitch needles Annie much to her disliking and promptly leaves the store. Annie manages to get his license plate number and decides to buy him some love birds, perhaps feeling she's misunderstood and this is a way to win him over. She drives the birds to the address she tracks down from his plate and drops off the birds. Mitch sees her and promptly catches up to her, asking her to stay for dinner. The birds in the area start to act a little aggressive and increasing in numbers. As usual, no one in the beginning believes the situation will get out of hand. I actually liked Jessica Tandy's character as Mitch's mother Lydia more often than I liked Mitch. Mitch convinces everyone to stay at the house and wait the attack out. Every good film has an antagonist and there are several in this film. The plot could have been developed more as far as how Annie and Mitch work out their differences. Lydia leaves the house one morning and we could swear Annie and Mitch hit the sheets during her absence, though nothing is shown except how affectionate and close they are when Lydia returns.One minor note is that Mitch's younger sister looks more like she could be his daughter, but this doesn't detract from the film. I enjoyed Suzanne Pleshette's teacher character and found her to be the most engaging character in the whole film.Overall, a good film with excellent directing, cinematography and film editing. The plot of how birds can increase in numbers and attack people is believable in my opinion, especially with today's bird flu epidemics and such. If you've ever eaten food on an East coast beach, some birds will swoop down at you with a few getting a little too close. I wasn't disappointed with the ending -- it leaves the idea of what happens next to both imagination and a possible sequence.

title: Hitchcock actually made birds scary.
content:
This is a movie I've only seen in pieces, mostly notably through the Kill Count in Dead Meat and that's pretty much it. Now that I've watched the movie in its entirety, I can say that The Birds is an easy Top 10 movies in Alfred Hitchcock's filmography.Positives for The Birds (1963):
Like his other movies, Alfred Hitchcock's direction and execution is done masterfully in this movie. I also have to give credit that Hitchcock actually made the birds in this movie scary and I don't even find birds to be that scary. I also have to say that the performances from the cast are phenomenal whether you're talking about Rod Taylor as Mitch Brenner, Jessica Tandy as Lydia Brenner, Suzanne Pleshette as Annie Hayworth, Tippi Hedren as Melanie Daniels and Veronica Cartwright as Cathy Brenner. I really enjoyed the little romance between Rod Taylor and Tippi Hedren, the grandmother of Dakota Johnson, as these two manage to give each other those "will they, won't they" interactions and it works perfectly. When the birds attack Bodega Bay, I was on the edge of my seat and I was scared to see whenever they started another attack on the town and there aren't a lot of movies that can do that successfully. And finally, the ending to this movie was deeply disturbing in a way that still makes you terrified by these birds.Overall, The Birds (1963) is another phenomenal entry into Alfred Hitchcock's filmography and while I already know that, I am still genuinely impressed with how consistently great of a filmmaker Hitchcock was.

title: A horror classic of a different type
content:
I saw this movie when it debuted. I was 9. It was pretty scary. Obviously, I (we), have taken it in a few more times since then.Hitchcock as usual does a good job. The setting is different from the book, but the essence is the same: Birds gone murderously berserk. I think his best creepy effect is the way he handles the amassing of crows at the school.The story is OK. My wife and I actually attended a small family reunion in Bodega Bay maybe 10 years ago. It was pretty there. I kept my eyes open for killer gulls but none appeared.Rod does a decent job. A little bit dour in personality maybe, but I figure that's only because he missed Weena (who he saved from the Morlocks.)Trippy Headcase did a bang up job. Around the same time, she also did "Marnie", a psychological Hitchcock thriller with 007 as the lead. Not a bad fare.I didn't even recognize Jessica Tandy as Rod's possessive mother. I discovered it on line. When I told my wife, she couldn't believe it. Everybody's so much younger obviously.I have one beef, and it's legit. Trippy shows up at the school to check on Rod's kid sister. Of course this is the scene I alluded to above. Trippy has just alerted the teacher as to the crows amassing outside. Both are alarmed, particularly in light of the very recent bird attacks, one, on Trippy herself.Taking this into account, and thinking of the children's safety first of course; they make the super intelligent decision about what to do with the (already frightened) young students. That's right, Send them outside at dusk, to walk (then run) home! Teacher Pleshette next, actually does indeed give strict instructions to the kids to quietly walk slowly until she instructs them to "RUN FOR YOUR LIVES!"Why didn't Plesh baby just say "OK kids, millions of bloodthirsty murderous crows are outside. Children's eyeballs are a delicacy of theirs. The last thing we want to do is keep you here, safe inside, preferably in another room with no windows. That's crazy! Somebody might get claustrophobic. Not only that, I couldn't contact your parents anyway, because a bunch of angry swallows broke into the filing cabinets earlier, and ate all the Emergency Contact Cards. So here's your homework assignment: Make it home alive! And if you don't show up for school tomorrow, you flunk!"
"Now get out there and pretend you're invisible. I'll tell you when to run & scream. Cover your eyes too, and run in a zigzag pattern, preferably in the middle of the street where you're less likely to run into things. Also, absolutely NO falling down and crying! Good luck! If you need us for anything, Trippy & I are going to stay safely inside, knock back some more brandy, and watch the show.""Ready Kids?!?"
"ON YOUR MARK!!"
"GET SET!!"
"CROW!!"So ridiculous.Other than that, The Birds is a Classic fun flick.Recommend especially for kids 7-12, and a one time viewing for any adult who has never seen it.Thx
Bob & Evelyn R.

title: Hitchcock at his best!
content:
Every now and then you come across a little gem of a classic,
and this is for sure one of those. Based on a short story by Daphne Du Maurier, it is a an unusual one . Yes of course it is dated, but not bad for 1963. For me a good film is if it captivates me while watching it and if it stays with me afterwards. I can definitely include this film there.Ya sure, a lot of flaws and some questionable decisions by the characters , but all in all an entertaining watch !

title: A Haunting Fairytale
content:
Fairytales, even those for kids, are seldom serene and innocent. Think of Little Red Riding Hood, Cinderella, Hansel and Gretel, full of mysterious and haunting characters imbued with evil.The Birds, released three years after Psycho, a gap relatively long for Hitchcock but explained also by the technical challenges of the production, contains all the trademarks typical of both his cinema style and the fairytales.
The blond and beautiful leading lady, much stronger and determined than the appearances suggest, the light initial tone, almost a comedy with the witty bickering of the main characters, the unmissable Hitch's cameo, the long and winding coastal road, the ingenious quotes of his previous movies, here The 39 steps and To Catch a Thief amongst others, are intertwined with the inexplicable evil and the helplessness of the darkest fairytales' personas.But The Birds, loosely based on a short story published in 1952 by Daphne du Maurier, an author that the English master had already used as a source for Rebecca and Jamaica Inn, is also deeply experimental and has a philosophical sophistication unrivalled by any of Hitchcock's movies.
Since the opening credits, evoking the optical expressionist illusions of Escher's birds, the film is imbued with a haunting introspection that is ultimately only enhanced by the lively beginning of the movie, when Mitch, an anonymous Rod Taylor, meets and squabbles with Melanie, Tippi Hedren on her cinema debut.
The director's choice of giving up a musical soundtrack, with the only music briefly played by Melanie on the piano and the nursery rhyme sang by the school children, skipping the end credits and a real, defined ending, the sophisticated special effects engineered for the birds' attacks, that all in all have well survived time and digitalisation, the dilution of time and pace challenging and almost mocking the viewer, like in the emblematic scene of the crows perched on the jungle gym, the unpredictable and random behaviour of the birds, the roles' reverse, with the humans forced by attacks and fear to look for protection into the cages, either houses, cars, bars, phone boots, coinciding with the mental cages built by the terror generated by the distortion of the natural order that everybody is used to and expects, make The Birds an overwhelming complex movie to watch and understand, difficult to define, in between horrors and thrillers and that in fact was not very much appreciated by both the critics and the public when released.
Only recently the first Hitchcock movie produced and distributed by Universal has been heralded as one of his bests and most likely his last masterpiece, as well as a trailblazer on the analyses of the sickness and inner demons of the human psyche.The Birds is a movie that leaves a long-lasting impression in the discerning viewer, notwithstanding the mediocrity of the actors, with the exceptions on an intense Jessica Tandy as Mitch's mother and a convincing Suzanne Pleshette as Annie, the sacrificial lamb of both Mitch and the birds.
Regrettably, the few films Alfred Hitchcock directed after The Birds, however well-crafted and a pleasure to watch, will not add anything to the film body of one of the most important filmmakers of the XX Century.

title: Amazing Effects
content: The Birds was made in 1963 for Christ sakes and yet the effects still amaze me because if you compare the effects for this film with the one in Jaws 3 the you'd think that this was made years before it. The bit where Melanie is stuck in the phone booth is my favourite bit because its well spoofed in the Simpsons, or the scene where that man is dead and his eyes are pecked out.I cant believe that it is being remade in 2009. They should leave things alone like with the ridiculous amounts of sequels like with Halloween or Friday the 13th.10/10

title: Movie Review: The Birds
content: The Birds is a classic Alfred Hitchcock horror/thriller that sees socialite Melanie Daniels travel to Bodega Bay to see lawyer Mitch Brenner, however soon after her arrival, swarms of birds begin attacking the town for seemingly no reason. The whole reason that the birds keep attacking is a mystery and the entire town is terrorized constantly to the point where people are actually getting killed by these flocks of birds. I really enjoyed this movie and to be honest, I don't really know where Alfred Hitchcock would get the idea of killer birds to begin with, but they definitely work as an interesting plot device. This movie has a great atmosphere with the Sunny Bodega Bay where it feels like a place where nothing could go wrong and the beginning of the movie really enforces that feeling where it seems like it will just be another romance plot. I would definitely recommend this movie to anyone who likes horror/thriller movies or to anyone that just wants to see a good Alfred Hitchcock movie.

title: Soooo boooooooooring
content: I watched this because my 10 year old daughter wants to watch it and being pg-13 I wasn't sure if she should be allowed. The first 70 minutes can be skipped. The suspense for me was getting that over with and seeing some action. The next 30 minutes you do see a little action but it's really just a tease. More suspense waiting for more action. Finally, the last 20 minutes you get to see the dystopian world you've been waiting for. But this is short lived and left open ended.Honestly, by the end of the movie you can't wait for it to be over. There's a bit of a campy feel to it. I'm a little disappointed actually, I expected more. No way my daughter makes it even halfway through this one lol.

title: Refreshingly creepy
content: There's something about birds in general that is just unpleasant.  The beaks, the flapping wings, the claws and dirty feathers.  I've always found birds to be a little bit unnerving and that's why I found Hitchcock's "The Birds" to be refreshingly creepy.Surprisingly, the effects (the birds) were remarkably realistic and effective.  The number of birds alone was uncanny.  There appeared to be thousands of them.  Certainly this excessive number of birds added to the horror of the film.The performances of the actors were very straightforward, and the story contained a number of bizarre story points or red herrings.  Hitchcock has used a large number of devices to surprise the audience just one more time, and keep us expecting more.  For this reason, I highly recommend watching this film more than once.

title: But it is realistic!
content:
I think The Birds is a masterpiece , but I can't explain why. Instead I'll
offer a rejoinder to anyone complaining that it isn't realistic. I have
seen that complaint registered against "Top Hat" and "The Wizard of OZ"
too.The book "Slime - How algae created us, plague us, and just might save us"
by Ruth Kassinger offers this account:The Santa Cruz Sentinel reported that on (August 18,1961) residents
Pleasure Point and Capitola wee awakened at 3 a.m. by the clattering and
thumping of a massive flock of seabirds-sooty shearwaters, to be precise,
with three-foot wingspans - diving into the roofs of their homes. The few
people who ventured out into their yards to investigate, armed with
flashlights, saw large birds littering the streets. Many were dead, but
some only stunned, and those, attracted by the flashlights, flew at the
townspeople. In the morning, residents found the streets covered in dead
shearwaters and "bits fo fish and fish skeletons over the streets and
lawns and housetops, leaving an overpowering fishy stench." Thirty years
later, a similar event occurred, only that time it was flocks of pelicanswith the bellies full of fish - that crashed into houses in the samecoastal towns.In both instances - and no doubt other that went unrecorded - the birds
were driven mad by a toxin they'd accumulated in their bodies. The fish
they'd eaten had scarfed up zooplankton that had in turn, swallowed a
certain species of micro algae, a diatom called Pseudo-nitzschia.

title: The Birds
content: A woman looking for love gets more than she bargained for when thousands of birds attack any human in sight in a sleepy coastal town called Bodega Bay.We first meet Melanie Daniels at a pet shop in San Francisco where she is intrigued by a dashing gentleman by the name of Mitch Brenner. He mentions to her that he is looking for love birds as a gift for his 11 year old sister. After tracking down his full name and address, she decides to surprise him with two love birds by traveling via boat to his family home in Bodega Bay. On the way, a seagull swoops down and hits her on the head causing her to bleed. As a gesture, Mitch invites Melanie to have dinner with him, his sister, and his mother at their house.Afterwards, Melanie meets Annie Hayward who is a local teacher and former girlfriend of Mitch. They both talk about Mitch's mother Lydia and how jealous she can be with any girl who gets close to Mitch. The next day at Mitch's sisters birthday party, a flock of seagulls attack the guests. Then it attacks a group of children leaving their school. With all different types of birds coming together to kill humans, can they be stopped? And will Melanie and Mitch survive the vicious attack on Bodega Bay?The Birds is one of Alfred Hitchcock's finest films of all times. His creative abilities made a movie about killer birds really come to life and be terrifying, when it could have been a bit of a joke if done by the wrong person. The idea of birds attacking us is a scary thought. There are billions of birds in the world so if for some reason they decided to attack we would be in serious danger. The Birds never gives us the reason for the attack which I like. It's almost scarier not knowing why this is happening to Bodega Bay.The acting is superb, led by Tippi Hedren as Melanie Daniels. She has a likability that she puts forth to the character, so we really root for her and admire her strength in battling the birds. Great character development by Hitchcock as well. She really connects with Mitch's sister Cathy played by a very young Veronica Cartwright. Also has a lot of chemistry with actor Rod Taylor who plays Mitch. His possessive mother is played wonderfully by Jessica Tandy.I highly recommend The Birds for it's creativity and high tension scenes involving the bird attacks. We get some vicious ambushes in there at times, and it placed me in the movie and made me think of how scary it would be if all of this was happening around us. The acting and character work was at a high level which also made viewers care for the characters. A great horror film overall.9/10

title: Possibly the best horror picture of all time
content: The mastery Alfred Hitchcock displays in the Birds has no comparison to any other horror movie ever. First of all, the characters are perfectly described and no mere cliches that nobody cares for (very usual in this movie genre). I wouldn't like to point any of them, but I think Melanie (portrayed by the beautiful Tippi Hedren stands above the rest). Also Jessica Tandy as Rod Taylor's mother is equally standout. That's important, very important in this type of movie, cause when they face danger, we CARE about their fate. Second, the birds. I think the most frightening scene ever seen on the silver screen, is that of the siege of the Breener's house (Rod Taylor's family). We see nothing,..but we HEAR ,thus allowing our imagination to think freely. And most important of all, Hitch does not give us an explanation on the subject, nor does he gives us a happy ending. It's pure horror. A masterpiece

title: Average and too overrated....
content:
Hitch, the master of suspense? Well, there's not much of it here...plus the ridiculous, almost non-existent plot, makes "The Birds" a little difficult to digest.
There's some great imagery in this movie, especially towards the end, and a couple of creepy/scary moments and that's about it.
Hitchcock always relied on absurd and/or illogical plots, but this one just goes too far. Also, the touches of comedy at the beginning (i.e the flirting between Hedren and Taylor) nullify the tone a horror movie must have. Mediocre, overall.

title: A great horror tale  with deep plot
content: The first time i saw it, i thought it was good, the second i realise it was great.Hitchcock knows how tell a story better than any director nowadays and it is shown in the attacks of the birds which may be thought just as "tries to scare audiences" but in the end they mean more than that .Tippi Hedren delivers a weird performance as the pet shop owner and the rest of the cast is good too.The attacks of the birds seem very real and look very cruel and the ending leaves you with a open interpretation. Overall, for fans of Hitchcock(like me) and for horro movie lovers 8/10

Other names: Common starling, English starlingOriginate from: Parts of Europe, Asia and AfricaReason in U. S.: A Shakespeare fan went too farDestructive superpowers: Destroy cropsNewsworthy moment: In 1960, a swarm of 10,000 starlings flew into a passenger plane taking off from Boston's Logan Airport, disabling the engines and causing a crash that killed 62 people.Eugene Schieffelin was such a fan of William Shakespeare that he decided to introduce a bird mentioned in his play Henry IV into the U. S. In 1890 and 1891, Schieffelin unleashed approximately 100 imported Europeans starlings into New York City's Central Park.Bad idea.Within 50 years, they had spread across the continent. Today, there are more than 200 million European starlings in North America; considered noxious and destructive, they compete with native species and destroy crops such as grains and pitted fruits. They swarm agricultural feeding troughs, contaminating food and water, and are linked with diseases like histoplasmosis, a lung ailment afflicting agricultural workers.The Maori soon discover their new found world is far larger than any islands their people have previously occupied. In fact New Zealand is a bigger landmass than all the Polynesian islands put together. Exploring the heavily forested interior it will not be long before they discover the islands top predator, a creature that will come to strike fear in the hearts of the Maori. The Haast eagle the largest and most deadly aerial predator the world has ever seen. It has a three meter wingspan, talons the size of tiger's claws that will crush the neck of a giant moa, a bird twenty times its weight. This is a specialist in crippling two-legged prey. When it first sets eyes on humans this pre-adapted man killer sees fare game. It swoops down on unsuspecting victims at speeds up to eighty kilometers per hour. This monstrous raptor remains by its kill for days. The Maori will speak of this giant carrying people away to feed its ravenous young.Red Tailed Hawks can take down animals 2 times their own size, like a children. Do eagles really try to snatch up babies? It's not common. Many attacks by eagles on children have been reported over the years, but it's hard to tell how many are accurate. Alfred Hitchcock had trained birds attack people, birds is based on a true story, in 1835 a large flock of black birds attack people on a streets in Boston.

title: Strong Suspense from the Master of Suspense
content: THE BIRDS is often listed amongst the great works of Alfred Hitchcock and I could never really understand the attraction. I thought it was a so-so fright-flick, so when I tripped across it on TV the other day, I started watching it with one eye, figuring I'd flip to something else in a few minutes.And...then I caught myself getting into it.Based on the novel by Daphne Du Maurier, THE BIRDS is told in Alfred Hithcock's suspenseful style to elevate a "pulp novel" idea of birds turning on humans to something much more tense than it had any right to be.Newcomer Tippi Hendren stars as wealthy San Francisco socialite Melanie Daniels who chases suave charismatic lawyer Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor) north of San Fran to his home of Bodego Bay. Will Melanie be able to win Mitch's heart over the objections of his mother (Jessica Tandy) and ex-girlfriend (Suzanne Pleshette)? We'll never know, for the Birds have their own idea of how this tale will end.Hitchock, of course, earns his nickname "The Master of Suspense" with this film. He has some long scenes that grow with tension. Whether it's Melanie crossing the Bay in a boat (only to, finally, be attacked by a bird) or Mitch's mother going down a long hallway to find out what happened to a farmer friend of hers to the famous - and famously pulled off - scene of the birds gathering en masse on the jungle gym prior to attacking Melanie and the school children. Hitchcock knows exactly how to raise tension in these scenes and he does so marvelously. Even 56 years later, I found what little hairs I have standing up on the back of my neck and my body bending ever so slightly towards the screen during these scenes.But...the thing that caught me this time around was the performances of the leads and the way Hitchock lets scenes play out with the actors. I've never been a big Rod Taylor fan, I've always thought he was "fine", but nothing special. He is much more than "fine" in this film. It's probably the best work I've ever seen him do. Jessica Tandy, of course, as the mother is wonderfully cold and distant to begin with and slowly moves to close to madness and then understanding, it is a wonderfully understated performance showcasing a superb theater actress. As is Pleshette's turn as school teacher Annie. Her scenes with Hendren were laced (I'm sure purposely) with an undercurrent of sexual tension between the two female characters.But...the star of this film is Tippi Hendren, beyond a doubt. Much has been made of the cruelty and misogynistic ways that Hitchock treated and abused Hendren in the making of this film. But her performance shone as the gold-digging, fun loving Melanie who descends into the depths as the film progresses. I've never thought much of her as a performer, but will have to check out other films of hers (most notably, Hitchock's MARNIE).The special effects - which were cutting edge and earned an Oscar nomination back in the day - are dated, but that adds to the charm of the film (at least for me). I'm sure they "wowed" the audience in 1963, so I'll cut them some slack.I was pleasantly surprised by the pacing, acting and SUSPENSE of this film. It has held up very well and if you haven't seen THE BIRDS in awhile, I recommend you check it out.Letter Grade: A-8 stars (out of 10) and you can take that to the Bank(ofMarquis)

title: Certainly A Classic
content: Probably the weakest Hitchcock film I've seen so far, but all his films are so great that it's hard to care. I honestly really liked the opening. The romantic tension really worked and the patient setup just helped to build suspense. Unfortunately, the first couple of bird sequences didn't really work for me. They felt quite choppy and the effects didn't hold up nearly as well as later on in the film. I was worried that this was going to end up being underwhelming, but the final few bird sequences elevated the film a whole lot. They were much more entertaining to watch and made sure the film ended on a high note. Hitchcock's direction is obviously great, and I really liked the lack of a score. Given that the score in Psycho became one of the most iconic scores of all time, it would have been easy to just replicate that score, so I appreciate Hitchcock going in a different direction with this score. The performances were really good, particularly Tippi Hedren in the lead role, and overall this was just a thoroughly entertaining film. If you're a bit Hitchcock fan, then you'll probably really like this.

title: So people got scared by Ravens and Seagulls?
content: Dear Mr. Hitchcock, you did not need to create a film to convince me that ravens and seagulls are incorrigible creatures, as I am well aware of their 'erratic' personalities.Anyway, this happens to be my third Hitchcock film (following Rear Window and Vertigo) and unfortunately, it is yet another disappointment.To be honest, I didn't even plan on watching it initially, but the abundance of positive reviews piqued my curiosity the other day, so I decided to give it a chance.Little did I know that all I would get is a mediocre amalgamation of genres, where both romance and thrill fail to leave a lasting impact.Maybe it's because I've been exposed to these specific genres too much, or perhaps it's due to the outdated approach that lies beneath, but I just couldn't connect with the tale or find myself caring for the characters, I adored the location, had fun with the technical sides but that's about it!
