title: A strong & frightening film.
content: The more times I view "The Birds" the more I understand the ending, but I do agree that at first I was not satisfied with it. I wanted the birds to either finish the job or to be challenged by something (Mitch did hear on Melanie's car radio that perhaps the military might be called in!) but we never saw anything like that. I guess that's why we have imaginations!'Tippi' Hedren was a beautiful cool blonde who played Melanie Daniels as she should have - icy and yet ultimately very vulnerable. Rod Taylor as Mitch Brenner seemed a good reason for her to travel to Bodega Bay. Jessica Tandy as Lydia was what you'd expect of an older, widowed, small town woman from that time. Suzanne Pleshette as Annie Hayworth, the school teacher, with her dark beauty was quite a contrast to Melanie and I felt awful at her death by the birds. Veronica Cartwright as Kathy Brenner was a little annoying when she cried but then that IS what young girls do!!A strong, frightening film but one of Hitch's best horror films. Decidedly not for children. Even Ingmar Bergman was a Hitchcock fan and lifted a scene from The Paradine Case and reworked it into Cries and Whispers! The relationships of The Birds have a 'Bergmanesque' quality as well and the Bodega Bay setting could as well have been Ingmar's Faro island. The film The Passion of Anna, deftly counterpoints the personal relationship with an unknown outside 'monster' who is killing and mutilating animals. Very much like 'The Birds' in spirit.The cast is very good too. Taylor is as perfect as the everyman hero as he was in THE TIME MACHINE. Jessica Tandy is excellent, playing a very irritating character and giving her some warmth and life despite her bad points. Veronica Cartwright is convincingly menaced, just as she was years later in ALIEN and INVASION OF THE BODY SNATCHERS. I didn't care much for Tippi Hedren's cold character the first couple of times I saw this, but her presence has subsequently grown on me in the intervening years.

title: Hitchcock at his 'beak'
content: Well, its Friday the 13th, of Aug. '99 of course, and someone from beyond the grave wants to spook you.Actually its Hitch's 100 rd birthday and what better way to spook you than with THE BIRDS.I first saw this movie as a child and it scared the pants off of me.I had nightmares for months after, like millions of other young people. Today I appreciate the mystery its conveys.In the movie we just don't know why the birds attack unprovoked but we're treated to some speculative ideas.Initially, Tippi Hedren gets the blame, the attacks starting when she arrives in Bodega Bay.Playing the character, Melanie Daniels, a rich daughter of a newspaper magnate,Hedren is labelled as 'pure evil' by one of the townsfolk.But this isn't right, you see Melanie is not even raven-haired, she's pure blonde.Hitch knows we won't fall for that old trick,so in comes a charute smoking ornithologist complete with feather in hat who blinds us with fact after fact about how sweet and nice our fine feathered friends are. The birds dispute this by their actions surrounding a cafe menacingly. naw,that's not the answer,back to the drawing board folks.So there is no explanation given except perhaps that the Bodega Bay residents were skimpy with the bird seeds that week and therefore the birds felt,er a little .. peckish.No it's just as if..as if your left in silence, like the silence of no movie score, or the silent scream of Jessica Tandy, or perhaps the silence of Hedren being peaked to death in the attic scene. Each element is like gathering a twig here, a sapling there,a leaf elsewhere and building them up into a nestling symbolism that comprises, stealth, secretiveness,mysteriousness and pure creepiness that eventually hatches under your skin.Technically unique,THE BIRDS uses various special effects ,such as, animation,models and live birds to stage the attacks.It's truly amazing, the school house attack being my favourite.But my overall favourite piece is when Rod Taylor tries to walk to his car at the end of the movie.A single perched crow turns its head and curiously looks up at Taylor then at his hand and bites it!!. Seagulls timidly peck at his pants and shoes,all the while cooing softly. In our minds were saying Rod get back in the house your outnumbered!! It's not truly anticlimactic,it's just pure suspense,anticipation of what might happen rather than does.It's also amazing that no other director,at least to my  knowledge, has pursued this aviaristic theme.There's a very funny story told by the director Peter Bogdanovich about Hitch.One day he was waiting for Hitch at some hotel somewhere and when they met,they got on an elevator to go down to the hotel lobby,some 20 stories below them. Hitch got in the back and the lift filled up with people.Suddenly Hitch starts to speak... "There was blooood eveerrywhere",he starts in his British accent. "Bloooood on the carpet,blooood on this chaps clooothing,blooood on the couch," Bogdanovich is trully puzzled,what brought this on, he thought,but he decides to chime in. "Really,Hitch?", "Yeeesss", drools back Hitch. The elevator stops somewhere on the 12th floor,there's an exchange of people and it moves off again. "Blooood streaming from his nose," continues Hitch, "His cloothes were a complete meess," Unable to escape the talking,people were cocking an ear or two to this diminutive,bald,rotund gentleman with the oh-so drool English accent. The elevator gets close to the lobby, Hitch goes in for the kill."GOOD GOD MAN,WHAT EEEVVVEEERR HAPPENED TO YOU?" continuing slowly he says, "..and do you know what he said to me"?The elevator reaches the lobby,doors part, and nobody appears to want to move. Hitch quietly makes his way out of the lobby trailed by a small contingent of people seeming to follow him.Bogdanovich comes up to Hitch's level. "Well, Hitch, what did the man say"? "Whaaat"? replies Hitch. "The man with the blood all over him". "OH thhhaat,...nothing..that was my elevator stooory", and walks on.

title: Alfred Hitchcock's Crowning Achievement
content: Dazed and confused by the pure brilliance of Hitchcock's greatest film, many critics sank to the cheap shot evaluation "It's for the birds," and thus undercut the initial box office for this picture. The laugh would come later as THE BIRDS scored whammy ratings over and over, every time it was played on TV, for decades. Based on a razor thin short story, Hitchcock elaborated into a multi-teared suspense drama juxtaposed with the strongly drawn romantic relationship between Tippi Hedrin and Rod Taylor. Hitchcock was the "master of suspense" but how many other of his films can match the raw suspense, hitting the viewer over and over, of this masterpiece. The answer is zero. PSYCHO's asset was shock; THE BIRDS was suspense. From the initial single bird attack at the docks of Bodega Bay, to the brilliant scenes at the schoolyard, to the unparalleled fear inside the boarded-up house, no other Hitchcock film even came close regarding suspense. The scene censored from early TV screenings, running 1.5 seconds, where Jessica Tandy enters her neighbor's farmhouse and finds him dead --- the fact that they'd cut 1.5 seconds says it all. The romance has real magic to it, and Hitchcock succeeds with this despite the absence of his trademark heavy-necking scene. Finally, the suspense factor obviously is gone after the first viewing; nonetheless this film stands up tall for multiple replays. An absolute classic.

title: Hitchcock always knew how to make use of chaos, and he takes it to the extreme here
content: Probably no motif appears in Alfred Hitchcock's movies more often than chaos. While it played a central role in "Shadow of a Doubt", "Strangers on a Train" and "Psycho", "The Birds" is probably the ultimate chaos story, especially considering how Hitchcock plays with the audience.It all begins when socialite Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren) enters a San Francisco pet shop and meets lawyer Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor). While they at first seem to be a little displeased with each other, Melanie then buys some love birds to give Mitch. When she goes to his apartment and learns from a neighbor that he's in Bodega Bay for the weekend, she promptly drives up there. That's when things start to get strange. A seagull pecks Melanie on the forehead while she is on a boat, and then a bird crashes into a schoolteacher's door.Finally, at a birthday party, a whole flock of birds attacks everyone. Then, a flock of birds gathers around a school and attacks the children as they're leaving. After a gas station explosion, it turns into full scale war; the chaos has irreversibly set in. Whereas in most movies, chaotic events get explained, they do not get explained in "The Birds", which adds to the terror.What I mean by "playing with the audience" is this: for about the first half hour, the movie seems to be a romantic comedy. Then, once the birds attack at the birthday party, everything changes; there's nothing that's going to save anyone now.A common theme in Hitchcock's movies is the guilty woman (think "Blackmail" and "Psycho"). Clearly, Melanie is a guilty woman, but guilty of what? Maybe this: she walks around in a fur coat, which identifies a disdain for animals. Perhaps the birds see her as the incarnation of everything bad that humans have done to animals, and so they take revenge on her.Nowadays when something bad happens in a movie, the solution is to have Sylvester Stallone or Arnold Schwarzenegger or Bruce Willis kick ass. Not so in "The Birds". Rod Taylor, whose character could easily be a "potent male adventurer", is helpless; seeing that the birds have essentially taken over Bodega Bay, Mitch boards up his house and hopes that the killer avians don't enter.The movie makes an interesting use of the color green. First and foremost are Melanie's clothes: her dress and blouse are lime-colored. Also, as she is driving to Bodega Bay, she drives through vast fields, meaning a lot of grass. What does this mean? Maybe that although Melanie is disconnected from nature, the latter is creeping up on her.I guess that an obvious point is that Tippi Hedren was one of Hitchcock's icy blondes, following Grace Kelly, Doris Day, Kim Novak, Eva Marie Saint and Janet Leigh. It's too bad that Tippi Hedren didn't do much after "The Birds"; she was hot in this movie.So, in conclusion, the next time you see a bird, just remember this movie, and especially remember the song that the schoolchildren are singing right before an ornithological onslaught. It might save your life...

title: Line your canary's cage with this.
content: Brokeback Mountain was a short story that was easily able to be adapted into a feature length film, despite covering decades of its characters' lives.This movie was based on a short story and totally feels like it.Desperate filler after desperate filler is the experience of this movie as we go through a parade of bland characters with null back-stories that only makes you more and more desperate to see someone get pecked to death.The long awaited scenes of avian aggression and suspense are pretty well realized but are truly not worth the wait.There is nothing to this except feathered friends inexplicably turning vicious which is kind of the point but after sitting through so much that was inconsequential it all feels insulting.No, I do not feel more empathy for these characters after seeing something of their human lives. No, it does not feel more terrifying to see regular life suddenly turn evil.Hitchcock isn't a particularly amazing film-maker; partly because mostly he just directs but he is a typical director who lucked out with some good scripts but THIS is not one of them.

title: "The Birds" had excellent special effects for the time period it was made in.
content: Alfred Hitchcock's film `The Birds' is an outstanding horror film and is very suspenseful, portraying different types of birds going psycho and attacking people. The birds somehow seem to be attracted to light in my point of view. Rod Taylor as Mitch Brenner and Tippi Hedren as Melanie Daniels who are the main characters are excellent actors. Even though most of the time the birds were fake both characters made it look as if it was really happening and they were really being pecked at. The whole idea of Evan Hunter writing a horror story about birds attacking the small town of Bodega Bay then Alfred Hitchcock making a movie out of it is a neat idea. What makes this movie so good is all the suspense and even though it was made in 1963 the graphics and special effects are awesome, even the sound effects of the birds flapping and screeching are good, and the sound is only in mono. Although I think the ending could have been better, the birds looked very real, as did everything else. I give this horror movie for the time period it was in a nine out of ten.

title: I love this movie to death You are a bird brain if you don't
content: I see this movie more as a wacky slapstick comedy but with dying rather than a horror movie. Birds just ain't scarry. I was laghing non stop. All the characters are very likeable.

title: I fell in love with Tippi Hedren!!!!!
content: Although I don't think that "The Birds" is Alfred Hitchcock's greatest film, it's very humorous, and obviously Hitchcock wanted to have a lot of fun with his audience. I like the way the film looks at the reaction of people to bizarre events, especially as some of the townspeople connect the arrival of the birds with the arrival of Tippi Hedren as though she somehow brought this on them. I didn't even notice that there wasn't a musical soundtrack the first time I saw the film, because the sounds of the birds attacking amidst the silence is really effective. "The Birds" features some great cinematography, a nerve-wracking soundtrack, and some finely wrought performances. "The Birds" is primarily famous for the sheer number of disconcerting and often stunning set ups it creates for the birds' attacks. And finally there's Tippi Hedren, the beautiful blonde discovered by Hitchcock after viewing her in a toothpaste commercial while Hitch was watching the Today Show. Hedren was one of the cool sophisticated blondes loved by Hitchcock (and this eventually led to problems on their next film, Marnie.) Tippi is just so classy and beautiful to look at and gives a very nice performance considering the fact that she had almost no acting experience. The film also led her to suffer a mini-nervous breakdown after having to endure days of having birds thrown at her during the film's climactic bird attack. Tippi is absolutely wonderful and was even better in a difficult role in her next (and last) Hitchcock film, Marnie. The film is also loaded with many interesting character actors in small roles: Charles McGraw, Richard Deacon, Lonny Chapman, Karl Swenson, etc. all giving entertaining performances.But the sheer brilliance of these set pieces is off-set by the overall film itself. Stories and scripts of Hitchcock films are usually very tight and very precise, but where "The Birds" is concerned you could drive a Mac Truck through the gaps. It is much easier to 'suspend disbelief' re the bird attacks than it is to accept the way in which the characters behave throughout the film. This is not actually the fault of the cast, which ranges from serviceable to excellent, but rather of the way the film works (or more specifically, doesn't work) as a whole. Having made up her mind to play a prank on Mitch, how is it that Melanie can't come up with a better one? Why evacuate the children into open air instead of an interior room? Why search for the source of a sound, alone no less, when you know what the source must be? Hitchcock knows how to build suspense and he does it quite convincingly with this movie. He casually starts off with what seems to be an average affair of two people and then those characters have sub plots that surround them and things get a little more tense until their "normal" world is thrown off balance by some thing that comes out of left field. This is great suspense film with a witty dialogue.Overall rating: 8 out of 10.

title: This movie gave me nightmares (My favorite Hitchcock)
content: Though it's not considered one of his masterpieces, 1963's The Birds is my favorite Alfred Hitchcock movie, a film that not only provides genuine scares, but is a master class in the art of cinematic suspense.Based on a short story by Daphne Du Maurier, this is the story of a wealthy socialite from San Francisco named Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren), who travels to a small Northern Californian town called Bodega Bay to pursue a possible relationship with the town's most eligible bachelor, Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor) and, upon her arrival, a series of unmotivated attacks by birds end up terrorizing the entire town.Other than the technical mastery and animal training that had to be involved in getting these birds to do what they were supposed to do when they are supposed to do it, this film shows what a master Hitchcock was at building suspense...watch the scene where Melanie is sitting on a bench smoking a cigarette while birds begin gathering on a jungle gym behind her or the scene before the final attack where Melanie, Mitch, his mother, and kid sister are sitting in the front room of the Brenner home waiting for a bird attack on the house. The suspense created in these scenes will have you either holding your breath or screaming at the screen for the characters to wake up.The wooden performances, especially Hedren, are irrelevant to the artistry that is Hitchcock that makes this classic a film that gave me nightmares for months and to this day, I still get very nervous when I see 3 or more birds gather in one location.

title: One Very Good Movie
content: This is one very good movie and I wish that they would make more like this one instead of those cheap class b movies.  I just bought it on dvd and watched it yesterday and I still get freaked out about certain parts in the movie and still am amazed at how they did this movie.

title: Warrants multiple repeat viewings
content: Despite the dodgy special effects this is a film that I can't help but watch every few years. It's mesmerising from start to finish. It may not be the best Hitchcock but it will probably always be my favourite.

title: More A Series Of Set Pieces Than A Coherent Film; Fascinating Nonetheless
content: Time has a way of qualifying our initial assessment of films, and this is particularly true of films made by director Alfred Hitchcock (1899-1980.) Throughout the 1930s and 1940s he was regarded as a solid craftsman but not an artist; in the 1950s many of his films, most notoriously VERTIGO, were received with lukewarm interest. In the 1960s, however, attitudes about his work began to change, and with that came a major re-evaluation of his films. Films that had been earlier dismissed were recognized as great classics; some films that had received tremendous recognition at the time of their release were now seen as somewhat over-praised.To a certain extent this re-evaluation continues today, and at this point one film in particular proves extremely contentious to critics: THE BIRDS, which was considered both extremely innovative and a great shocker in 1963 but which is now teetering on the brink of critical dismissal. Just as it took some thirty years to fix VERTIGO's position in the Hitchcock lexicon, so may it take fifty to arrive at a final summation here.According to film lore, Hitchcock was intrigued by a newspaper story about a "bird attack," and his interest in the story gradually evolved into THE BIRDS. (Although technically based on the 1952 novella by Dauphne du Maurier, the story and film bear little relation to each other.) The story developed by Hitchcock and Evan Hunter concerned slightly wild San Francisco socialite Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren), who becomes infatuated with Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor) and whimsically follows him to his home at Bodgea Bay as a prank. Not long after her arrival, however, she is attacked by a seagull, and although her injuries are slight she is quickly, albeit somewhat unwillingly, received by Mitch and his circle. One attack soon leads to another, and before very long Melanie, Mitch, and the entire community are under siege.THE BIRDS is primarily famous for the sheer number of disconcerting and often stunning set ups it creates for the birds' attacks. Two of these are particularly famous. While Melanie sits on a bench outside the grade school, her attention is attracted by a flying bird--and she turns to find the playground's jungle gym covered with crows, assembling for an attack as the children leave the school. Later, when the birds attack the town itself, Melanie is trapped in a telephone booth, a helpless witness to the horrors around her even as the birds begin to batter the glass that protects her.But the sheer brilliance of these set pieces is off-set by the overall film itself. Stories and scripts of Hitchcock films are usually very tight and very precise, but where THE BIRDS is concerned you could drive a Mac Truck through the gaps. It is much easier to 'suspend disbelief' re the bird attacks than it is to accept the way in which the characters behave throughout the film. This is not actually the fault of the cast, which ranges from serviceable to excellent, but rather of the way the film works (or more specifically, doesn't work) as a whole. Having made up her mind to play a prank on Mitch, how is it that Melanie can't come up with a better one? Why evacuate the children into open air instead of an interior room? Why search for the source of a sound, alone no less, when you know what the source must be? Hitchcock apologists tend to justify these and many other loose ends in the film by stating that THE BIRDS is intended to have an open-ended structure without resolution and that the random and often incomprehensible nature of the script is intended to reflect the random and incomprehensible nature of the bird attacks. A typical argument in favor of the film also notes that the film is driven by themes instead of plot points. Well-- maybe. But I'm an "art film" fan myself, and I can't see it.In the final analysis, THE BIRDS is more akin to modern ultra-commercial action and adventure films than it is to an art-film, with the action and adventure distracting you from the holes in the thing--including the fact that the film is surprising slow. Even so, while THE BIRDS has major flaws, it is so crammed with iconographic moments and visuals that it is impossible to completely dismiss the film as a commercial wallow pure and simple. At its best, THE BIRDS has an incredibly high level of artistry, and those moments really do carry the film and impress themselves in your mind in a most remarkable way. I offer my own experience as an example. I first saw THE BIRDS on television when I was a teenager, and although I thought it was entertaining enough I wasn't particularly impressed. The next morning, however, I opened the living room curtains--startled a flock of birds perched on the outside window sill--and I was scared half to death. And that's cinematic power, nothing else.The DVD presents the film in excellent form and includes several bonuses, most particularly Hitchcock's darkly humorous movie trailer and outlines of a deleted scene. Final comment: it's extremely uneven, but it is also extremely powerful. Recommended.GFT, Amazon Reviewer

title: The frightening vengeance from Nature
content: From the idea that common birds could attack people for no reason, the suspense master Hitchcock created a classic thriller. From ancient times, Men dominated birds, caged and embalmed them as trophies. What would happen if, suddenly, all the birds joined together and rebelled against us? The answer is given on the movie: we wouldn't have a chance of surviving. The movie is based on a story by Daphne Du Maurier. The difficulties of carrying out this task were enormous. The special effects were huge for that time, when there were no computers. Ubi Werk won a nomination to the Oscar for Best Visual Effects, but lost the prize to Cleopatra. Hitchcock used several kind of birds to simulate the attacks: real birds, trained birds, mechanical birds and even embalmed ones. In the beginning, The Birds is like a romantic movie, with the casual encounter of Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren) and Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor) in a pet store. But when Melanie travels to Bodega Bay to surprise him with two love-birds, the movie twist the mood. A seagull attacks Melanie and, suddenly, the birds start to attack people everywhere. The blood becomes visible, the destruction and the dead appear in all Bodega Bay area. Hitchcock appeals to successive and quick big plans to show the victims of this mysterious evil. The visual horror is combined with silence, only interrupted by the sound made by the birds. Robert Boyle, who was responsible for the scenarios, said that he was inspired by the painting The Scream by Edvard Munch, for the feeling of desolation and madness in a kind of inner solitude. One of the mythic scenes of the film is when, near the school, Tippi Hedren, dressed with the green tailleur she wore during the all film, is seated in a bench smoking a cigarette. We hear the children singing in school and, slowly, the crows begin to join behind her. A little later, there are hundreds of crows, quiet, waiting to attack. It's interesting that the director who always approached the theme of guilt, and how this guilt affected people, made a movie where the evil appears, in a pure state, and where the guilt isn't there.

title: Deeply unnerving thrill ride.
content: The Birds, released in 1963, is a deeply unnerving thrill ride and really a lot of fun. Another of Alfred Hitchcock's masterpieces, the film focuses on the idea of birds uniting against man in mysterious fashion. I enjoyed this concept of birds from different species retaliating against human kind for our crimes against them. It gives The Birds a uniquely alarming and disturbing quality by making something generally viewed as innocent and giving it a touch of evil. The films slowly builds with a distinct eeriness that is attributed to the bold score and increasingly unsettling imagery. The Birds blends beauty with terror and is just a realistic feeling thrill. Hitchcock captures many simple shots that are perfectly fitting and terrifying in context. I was sucked into the film early on, as Hitchcock's work has a knack of doing, with the intriguing personality of Melanie Daniels. Ms. Daniels is played by Tippi Hedren, in what's a convincingly dramatic performance, particularly in the final act. Daniels love interest is San Francisco lawyer Mitch Brenner, played charmingly by Rod Taylor. There are some good performances to be found here, but perhaps the best actors/actresses were the birds themselves. This is a film that can be a lot of fun for horror fans and a bit shocking, yet intoxicating for the average movie fan.

title: Not Hitchcock's best film
content: The Birds stars Rod Taylor and Tippi Hedren and is directed by Alfred Hitchcock. The film follows Melanie Daniels who decides to pursue a relationship with a criminal defense attorney at Bodega Bay. But her plans are cut short when a group of birds attack her and the residence of Bodega Bay. As much as I love a good Hitchcock movie, I have to say that this one is not his best. Don't get me wrong getting terrorized by a flock of birds is pretty scary and having them perched on your house, car, to just about anywhere is creepy and eerie. This movie however can't make up its mind on whether it's a romance or a horror movie. This film does provide great acting, dialogue, sound mixing, but where was the score? I understand that Hitchcock wants to give us a good scare but having no music for a two hour movie gets to be pretty boring and awkward at times. The music does work during the last hour of the movie, but before that happens we're left in that awkward state of mind if anything is going to scare us. So in the end, while this film does provide some creepy eerie scenes, the movie misses its target that gives us a two film where the first half is romance and the other half provides the horror. And this would've been perfect had the two found a middle ground instead of giving us a confusing film.

title: The Birds, one of Hitchcocks thrillers
content: I only just watched the birds about three days ago, its the sort of film that's sort of disturbing, what i mean is that when the birds come down and peck you on the hand and body you could almost feel it, and it's one of the most Fictional films i have ever seen in years, no don't get me wrong it's a good film but unlike other horror's like Psycho and scream its not reality because if you think about it, it's not every day that a bunch of birds will invade a small little town.

title: A Hitchcock Classic
content: The Birds is an Interesting movie to say the least, a horror movie that is totally plausible and a concept that drew people's attention to the film. The film has some amazing suspenseful moments and dramatic scenes. This movie screams hitchcock and only somebody like him would come up with a movie like this one.

title: "Don't they ever stop migrating?!"
content: THE BIRDS is a mysterious horror drama about an inexplicable conflict between the innocent creatures and the greatest enemy of nature. It is loosely based on the 1952 story of the same name by Daphne du Maurier.The main protagonist is a young woman, who is known for compacting inappropriate jokes and misbehavior in public. One day, she meets a charming lawyer in a San Francisco bird shop. He wants to purchase a pair of lovebirds for his sister's eleventh birthday, but the shop has none. He had seen her in court once before when her recklessness resulted in the breaking of a plate glass window, but she does not know him. He plays a prank by pretending to mistake her for a salesperson. After his departure, she becomes curious and decides to know him better. She finds his weekend address in Bodega Bay, purchases a pair of lovebirds, and makes the long drive to deliver them. The two of them meet again. However, something else is in the air ...Mr. Hitchcock has replaced his traditional tense story with an extreme mystery. He has, through a bizarre apocalyptic atmosphere, a frivolous romance and an idyllic life philosophy, made a symbolic game of destruction. His allegory, in which good and evil are a sort of metaphor, is excellent. The story is intriguing and unfortunately average, but the direction is very good.Hitch plays with visual effects and sound elements. He constantly enhances his horror, through scenes of massacred bodies, explosions and hysteria. The protagonists are constantly exposed to danger and none of them are safe. The fear has changed their character. A psychological or just logical explanation, that is cause of animal attacks, is absent.Characterization is good, while the performances is a bit wooden.Tippi Hedren as Melanie Daniels is a beautiful and dangerous blonde. She is the main carrier of a danger and reason at the same time. She is an exotic phenomenon in an idyllic landscape. The term "heroine" is perhaps too strong, but her performance indicates that notion. Rod Taylor as Mitchell "Mitch" Brenner is her support and better segment of their romance. His character is torn by three women. Jessica Tandy as Lydia Brenner is confused, lost and frightened in a complex role of a mother. Suzanne Pleshette as Annie Hayworth is a bit sinister and jealous as an ex-girlfriend, but her performance is the most realistic in this movie.Maestro has offered a bit "malicious" end.

title: An actress was amazing cute!
content:
An infamous lady as a gossip girl went to a country to get back at a man. But birds' having turned violent happened there. Even the setting was cool!Taking a closer look, the birds were scary. The feet were more dangerous than the beak. They are a kind of beasts exactly.
I was sure that key's birds from Harry Potter were based on this movie. Particularly a shot of getting beaks in a door was just that! I was afraid of just flying birds.

title: Suspenseful & Scary
content: One of Hitchcock's most popular movies, "The Birds" proves his reputation as "The Master of Suspense." There are many suspenseful and scary moments. You see the gas pooling around the vehicle as the idiot lights his cigarette at the pump. You see the birds gathering menacingly to...do what? Hitchcock's timing is perfect as the scene resolves as you knew it would.My favorite character is the ornithologist (amateur, I presume) lady at the gas station. She is so sure that birds would never behave in the manner described that you are almost eager for them to prove her wrong!I have seen the movie several times and enjoyed it very much. But it doesn't make my list of top Hitchcock films because it is more predictable than many others. And I found the ending dissatisfying.Want great characters and plot development? See "Vertigo" or "Rear Window."Plot twists? "The Man Who Knew Too Much" or "Psycho."Want a big surprise at the end? Try "North by Northwest."A superb adaptation of a Daphne duMaurier story? "Rebecca."Great acting? Any of the above, or "Strangers on a Train."An entertaining evening watching a relatively easy-to-follow plot by one of the greatest directors ever, while munching on your popcorn? Now you can see "The Birds."

title: Rats with wings, do your thing
content: As Hitchcock movies go, "The Birds" is definitely lower-rung; which surprises me greatly after that teaser trailer, honestly one of the best I've ever seen. I like that the monster is a bloodthirsty swarm, but the suspense just isn't there. Lots of buildup, though; no one's attacked for a good fifty minutes into the film, it's just Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor's awkward back-and-forth (their relationship is weird, man) followed by long stretches of panicky dialog between townspeople. Hitch really spaces out the kills in this film.When the movie actually comes to life, it's fantastic. The main characters are barricaded in the house, irate birds are pecking through the front door and crashing through windows; the sound design here is incredibly effective; escape is in doubt and the terror is real. It's here that I can see why "The Birds" is so revered.But all of this is in the film's final stretch, so gear up for the long haul.

title: The Birds was a fantastic horror movie
content: Alfred Hitchcock's film `The Birds' was an outstanding show. Teamed up with Evan Hunter, Alfred Hitchcock made a very suspenseful movie. It was a good idea not to add music it added even more suspense. This horror film also had some pretty good special effects for being made in 1963.  I thought the birds were very lifelike. It was awesome how he thought of making a film about different birds going crazy and attacking the small town. I would have never thought that birds could go crazy and attack people. I especially thought the scene with the children running down the hill was very lifelike. Even though the birds were probably fake, it really looked like they were pecking the children. I thought Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor worked really well together as the main actors. This film had me constantly wondering what would happen next. I give this film a rating of 9 out of 10.

title: My own theories!
content: i only watched this film because i had heard so much about it and it was being shown on ITV new years day. I found the film to be good for the time it was made, and it had an interesting story... but i haven't been able to stop thinking about it since i watched it! the birds just cant attack for no reason, so i came up with the following conclusions: 1) in the bird shop at the beginning, mitch says to Melanie that the birds shouldn't be kept in captivity.. (i cant remember the exact words) but it made me think about whether the birds were attacking because they didn't like the lovebirds being in the cage, and as they were all different species of birds attacking, i thought whether they were sticking together and therefore making the people in the film feel like they are in captivity themselves. 2) the birds only seem to attack when there is fire/smoke. when Melanie is at the school, she lights a cigarette, the birds come. when the lady in the café towards the end is playing with the match to light her cigarette, the birds appear, and in the final bit in the house, the light a fire and Melanie gets attacked.i am sure i will think of more, but please do post and tell me what you think of my theories!

title: Don't bother if you value your sanity
content: Alfred Hitchcock: depending on you, you will either love him or hate him with all your guts. If you like barf-causing horror and suspense to render your limbs into jelly, as well as a un-foreseeable twist, then this is your movie. It is appreciatable, no matter what. But if you are a person who appreciates movies that make you roar with laughter and recall it the next night with a smile, you will HATE this movie. It will render you to a trembling mass of nerves, and leave you fuming with outrage at the end. If you appreciate suspense, mystery, twists and a movie that will keep your eyes glued to the screen, you could not find a movie to beat The Birds. Otherwise, leave it well alone.

title: Weaker Hitchcock
content: But it is still fun if you enjoy a good monster story.Fortunately, the movie doesn't waste time trying to explain 'WHY' this thing happens. Something that happens in almost 90% of monster movies at the opening on act III. Yeah, usually before the big climax the heroes find time to light a cig and speculate about why things happen.Acceptable pacing, tension and acting. Not the best, not the worst. A good monster movie. A weak Hitchcock.

title: A Great Film, But Not Hitchcock's Best
content: I had previously watched Alfred Hitchcock's 'Psycho' (1960), and absolutely loved it, and was looking forward to viewing future Hitchcock films, so I rented this one. I did enjoy it.It tells the story of Melanie Daniels (Tippi Hedren), the daughter of a rich head of a newspaper, who is in a bird shop after minor birds, when she meets Mitch Brenner (Rod Taylor), a lawyer who remembers seeing her in court after she supposedly jumped into a fountain. He is after love birds for his little sister Cathy, as a gift for her 11th birthday. He pretends to think she works there, and waits until she makes a fool of herself, and lets birds out of their cages. There are none in stock, so Mitch heads elsewhere. Melanie's minor birds aren't going to be in yet, so she goes after him, and sees his license plate, and calls it in, and gets his address.Melanie gets some love birds and takes them to his apartment, only to learn that he has gone up to Bodega Bay, about an hour and half from San Francisco, where he and Melanie live, where he goes every weekend to visit Cathy and his mother. Melanie decides to drive up there personally to deliver the love birds. But when she arrives, birds of all sorts, from gulls to black birds and crows, thousands of real birds and about 400 trick shots, swarm Bodega Bay, and Melanie and Mitch must put their differences aside, and fight for their lives.The film has plenty more good acting, with Jessica Tandy playing Lydia Brenner, Mitch's and Cathy's mother, who has a distaste for Melanie, and any woman associated with Mitch, as she is afraid of being abandoned, like she was when her husband died, and Suzanne Pleshette playing Annie Hayworth, the Bodega Bay School Teacher, who is in love with Mitch, though denies it to Melanie.I did enjoy this film, but it is very far from Hitchcock's best, which would most likely be Psycho (1960), or Rear Window (1954). It is in full colour, which would most likely lower the suspense level, but I enjoyed it all the same.Beau's Rating: **** out of *****

title: Little character development
content: This movie is definitely gripping in parts but why on Earth do the birds attack only at certain times? This is never really revealed. The development of the characters is also wafer thin. Having said that, this is a genuine Hitchcock thriller. It came during the peak of the great masters powers films like Rear Window,Vertigo, North by Northwest, Psycho, and the Birds all appearing within a ten year period. Hitchcock's earlier and later films with the possible exception of Frenzy in 1972 never quite seemed as captivating as what Hitchcock produced in the 50s and early 60s. It featured the debut of the masculine Australian actor Rod Steiger who went on to become a widely respected actor. Hitchcock's fascination with blondes continues with Tippi Hedren in this case being the leading lady. The location of Bodega Bay, California seems ideal and portrays the intended isolation quite nicely. A little more meaningful dialogue and character development would have been all that this needed to become a true and timeless classic. Well worth a watch.

title: A Hitchcock Classic
content: What a different take on horror for the time. Nature strikes back. Alfred Hitchcock masterfully centers this modern horror classic around his muse, Tippie Herdron. The film is ahead of its time with its stunning visual effects, despite the fact that they may appear crude by today's standards. The film really pushed the envelope into the scary and the grisly. Rod Taylor is very compelling. The entire cast is terrific. Catch Hitchcock in his signature cameo in the opening Pet Store Scene. This is a must watch in filmmaking and horror. Aside from Psycho it is Hitchcock's most memorable film, in my opinion.

title: This is a horror classic and very methodically put together; however, it's far from Hitchcock's best work
content: The Birds (1963) is a movie that I recently watched for the first time in a long time on Netflix. The storyline follows a game of cat and mouse between a rich young lady and a young fella who is playing not to like her to catch her interest. When she travels to a San Francisco suburb to surprise him almost immediately after arriving in town the birds go berserk and start attacking people. What is causing this behavior and will they stop or take over the world?This movie is directed by icon Alfred Hitchcock (Psycho) and stars Rod Taylor (Inglourious Basterds), Tippi Hedren (Marnie), Jessica Tandy (Driving Miss Daisy), Veronica Cartwright (Alien), Suzanne Pleshette (The Bob Newhart Show) and Bill Quinn (Twilight Zone: The Movie).This will always be one of the more overrated Alfred Hitchcock movies. This wouldn't even make my top 10 films from him. The fake backdrops aren't great and how pressed the main character was to land her love interest didn't feel authentic. However, the casting and acting is top notch. The beach, school and home attacks were very well done and are entertaining every time I watch those sequences. Some of the special effects are dated, but the attack scenes are very good and the birds sitting outside the house are menacing. It is cool how much work went into training of the birds and how they used an actual haunted school to film the school scene. Sigourney Weaver's uncle is in this movie too.Overall, this is a horror classic and very methodically put together; however, it's far from Hitchcock's best work. I would score this an 8/10 and strongly recommend it.

title: Boring
content:
I don't understand why anyone is scared over this movie. Its not scary. There are some strange elements, but this movie works more as an unintentional comedy than a horror movie. That's actually giving this thing a lot of credit as for the most part its so boring that its not even worth watching as a comedy.The only reason why anyone is going to give this movie a high review is because 
a) They're a fan of Alfred Hitchcock
or b) they were somehow scared by it.Acting - All the acting is very bad. Its like the only direction anyone got was "just say your line." Everyone is terrible and unconvincing. The characters themselves are very dull. Some of the people did seem to be trying, but overall everyone failed miserably.Characters - Most of the characters act like total idiots and in general don't act like people. Motivations are very random and nothing is very well established. None of the characters are interesting enough to want to follow.Birds - Except for a few of them, the majority of the birds are very fake. I realize that it would have been able to coordinate that many birds, but it just kinda takes you out of the movie. There is a very long scene early on in the movie were the main character is driving in a car. Between the painfully long shots of the woman driving, there are up close shots on the birds in a cage in the car. Both of them are fake. This scene really sums up most of what is wrong with this movie - its an overlong scene with bad effects, a hint of comedy that is ruined by how long it is, and a moment to think about how boring the story it is. Some annoying woman is driving to some obscure location to give some guy she's met once a bird. What an entertaining premise. Honestly any other movie would condense what this movie drags out for almost an hour into about 10 minutes.Plot - This movie is way longer than it needs to be. Most of the scenes are way too long, and there are a ton of shots that could easily just be cut. The plot itself is already very dull an it doesn't need to be feature length. A lot of this movie is random filler designed to bloat the run time. I explained the basic premise in my previous point.Sights and Sounds - The audio and visual composition of this movie are pretty good, considering how old it is. Too bad its accompanied by terrible acting and a boring plot.I guess there is some potential in this movie. Maybe? Its just to boring for me to recommend it to anyone. I guess its not as bad as it could've been, but its not very good.

title: A classic from Hitchcock, mainly due to all the discomfort it generates in the audience, whether by the suggestion of ideas through and danger through which the characters go
content: When Hitchcock released Psycho in 1960, he was getting himself into a lot of trouble. The movie that would follow his great classic would have to be good enough to please fans, hungry for a new horror story that was as good as the last. Unfortunately, that never happened, but he presented us, in his fiftieth film, with a work totally different from anything he had done before: The Birds, from 1963. As in some other works, he left crime as a backdrop. In its story, focusing on further psychological development of the characters. In "The Birds" we don't have a killer. But we still have the suspense, the mystery, the fear, only this time with a certain supernatural tone. An extremely different route from what he is used to producing. There is no killer, but a group of apparently crazy birds that are attacking everyone in the city.One of the ways of looking at the work is its "disconnection" from Hitchcock's filmography, and I don't take this as a negative point. We have here a terror linked to nature that gives the work an exploitation veil, especially since there is no way to explain, combat or affirm that the problem was about to end. There is no murderer here, but a series of events that, in the end, will not be resolved! That's right, don't expect Hitchcock to chew for you all the philosophy inside The Birds. There's a constant supernatural tone, and that helped a lot to not have that need for the film. It also doesn't have the famous 'The End', just for people to think about everything they had just watched. After everything that happens in the movie, it just ends. The main focus, in fact, is not the attacks, but the psychological fear of people about something they never imagined could be dangerous. The focus is to work on people's subconscious, to make them fear the least fearful things possible. And it worked, at least at the time, since today the movie doesn't scare so much.The Birds is a model when it comes to building the atmosphere of suspense and, often, horror. The real war waged by the birds that storm the small Bodega Bay, a town close to San Francisco, can be easily read as a kind of material projection of the jealousy of Lydia Brenner (Jessica Tandy), a mother who sees the beautiful and famous Melanie as threatens, as she hangs around with her son Mitch. In fact, the angle of perception is offered almost on a platter by Hitchcock himself, in a certain conversation between Melanie and Mitch's old suitor.However, there are several elements that, chained with precision, add complexity to the film. An example is the marked contrast between the metropolis and the interior, an artifice here far from being banal, since it exposes in the coastal idyll a dynamic of relationships governed by somewhat retrograde moral codes. There is also the creation of sexual tension between the protagonists, at first in a bird shop (in a scene of equal subtlety and efficiency) and gradually throughout the narrative, the later arrival of Melanie at Bodega Bay, the first and apparently random attack by a seagull, the realization that physically mother and suitor look alike (more psychology in the vein), among others. Everything converges to the chaos that will soon ensue. The big problem with The Birds is that the text by Evan Hunter, based on the book by Daphne Du Maurier, ends up introducing or dilating some events entirely unnecessary to the general plot. A ninety-minute story ends up stretching for two hours, generating a great and undue slowness in the initial parts, which rely on dispensable approaches from certain characters, who gain back stories, only to be underused or discarded later.Hitchcock would make The Birds one of his most controversial films, both for critics and for his fans, who expected a more palpable horror, characteristic of the director. Like most of his films, Hitchcock presents us with a female character who goes against the conventions of the time in which the films are set, always putting them ahead of their time. At the same time that Melanie arrives in the city, the attacks of birds begin, an omen that she is the point of imbalance and these offensives appear when there are conflicting and emotional relationships. Mitch's mother, Lydia (Jessica Tandy) like other mothers in Hitchcock's works, is controlling, jealous, domineering and her son's new girlfriend doesn't seem to be in her good graces, only when Melanie seems most vulnerable, most dependent is her son. Mother-in-law seems to support her.The similarity between the birds' revolt and Melanie's avant-garde attitude is visible when we get to the last moments of the film: after being directly attacked and totally handed over to Mitch's family, the end is apocalyptic and the birds cease their attacks. Melanie is totally tamed and no longer presents any danger to that city. It's interesting how the director doesn't offer any explanation for the attacks and still manages to keep the viewer's attention.The film has already gained all kinds of possible interpretations, from symbolic, mystical, psychoanalytic issues to political situations typical of that moment of the Cold War (the birds as a communist invasion, etc.). But the plot is always giving an account of casual relationships, disguised by a certain belligerence and that the moment they become strong, they receive an external call: the struggle for survival, the end of amenities. Regardless of what motivated the birds' attack, the film easily guides the two spheres of transformation, internal and external to the characters, which develop in contrast. A frightening story of behavioral changes and transformation of the beautiful and ordinary into a cause for fear. And all for inexplicable reasons.The Birds is a thriller built on the uncertainty of what is in front of the viewer, something fragile and vulnerable like birds, which change the lives of the inhabitants of the small coastal town of Bodega Bay, California. Although it develops slowly, the fear of the unexpected that the film causes us comes from the unpredictability of elements of nature. Escaping the human ineffability present in past plots, which functioned as a kind of cautionary tale - a story that warns the viewer about an imminent danger.Hitchcock was nothing short of brilliant (he often was in the 1950s and early 1960s), calming the nerves of viewers who came to see the film just to see the bird attacks. As the first one only takes place after 50 minutes of projection, the director offered some "appetizers" for the impatient: he filmed a solitary lunge of a seagull here, showed a crowd of crows lined up on pole wires at another time... And, in that, satisfied the spirits of the most daring, and, even more, created an almost supernatural atmosphere of dread, a feeling that something very wrong is happening, but we don't know what (and this annoyance will only increase as the film progresses), making his work gradually more exciting.And in this movie, we know absolutely nothing about what's going on! We are as lost as the characters, with the exception of a small scene in the middle of the film, which precedes an attack by crows. The sensations evoked by Hitchcock in this feature are no longer of apprehension, tension or expectation for what will happen to the characters. Here, we are nothing short of terrified by what can happen, since the behavior of birds (and even that of some characters) is totally unpredictable, bringing out in each of us the fear of the unknown.The birds' attacks are perfectly executed and still impress us today not only because of the difficulty of execution by the technical standards of the time, but also because of the impression they leave on us. The attacks get progressively worse, first with some seagulls, some crows, until we reach an almost apocalyptic scenario in which the birds take over Bodega Bay, causing chaos. To relativize the importance of such marks of time in the effects part, it is enough to realize that the strength of the film lies in the narrative ingenuity. Each flight of a bird gains in significance beyond the "present" image, this is why we are led from the beginning, and little by little, to perceive every aerial movement as suspicious and even deadly. The scene in which the crowds gather, one by one, perched on the toy in the courtyard of the local school, is proof of that. In principle, no big deal, even with that exaggerated gathering, but in fact we feel the latent, silent fear, once we understand in advance the danger of stalking.Through sounds, edits and tricks, killer birds provide us with a unique sensory experience. "The Birds" does not have a soundtrack. Composer Bernard Herrman, Hitchcock's former partner, appears in the credits only as "sound consultant" and the idea of not using any score in the feature came from him. The creation of the atmosphere is largely through production design, which, oblivious to Hitchcock's compositional skills, made everything framed through the director's lens become innovative and inventive.In the end, it is quite clear, therefore, why The Birds became this well-known work by Alfred Hitchcock. It is not one of his best works, but it is certainly one of the most impressive, mainly due to all the discomfort it generates in the audience, whether by the suggestion of ideas through linked shots, or the punctual use of violence, blood, that settles, once and for all, the danger through which the characters go. Problems in the script, involving the unnecessary expansion of the plot and slips in the construction of the characters, therefore, do not diminish this great suspense of the master of the genre, who showed again everything he learned in these many years of experience. His prolific career, of course, doesn't end there, but The Birds is still a farewell, like the last of this legendary director.

title: Scary, bizarre and well done, but not true to DuMauriers story
content: Melanie - Tippi Hedren - meets Mitch - Rod Taylor - at a pet store in Frisco. Its a rather acrimonious meeting yet something about Mitch intrigues her. He was there to by lovebirds for his younger sisters birthday. Alas, the store has none. When Mitch leaves, Melanie finds out the store can receive lovebirds the next day. On a whim, Mel buys the birds but learns Mitchs weekend home is in Bodega Bay, an hour north. She drives up and tries to slyly deliver them by boating up to the house. Mitch catches sight of her and gives chase. Suddenly, a seagull flies into Melanie's head. Odd. Soon, Mitch bandages Mel and invites her to Sister Cathy's bday party. She meets the family, which includes Mitchs mother. Even so, more strange bird happenings occur. A farmer is attacked and killed by birds while a huge flock dive bombs children walking home from school. What in the world is making birds a dangerous enemy of humans ? This scary but well done film is a Hitchcock classic. The premise of "what if" permeates the tale, with frightening images of menacing birds. The cast is also wonderful, with Jessica Tandy, Suzanne Plechette and Veronica Cartwright complimenting the 2 stars. However, Dumauriers story is transformed from the setting to the characters to the ending. Perhaps someday a film of the original story will compliment this one.

title: Tough to Score
content: I intensely dislike the open ending of this movie, and have trouble bonding with the character of Melanie, but there's also no denying that this is a great film.Scary as heck, this movie sets up a very vivid confrontation of "mankind versus nature," with the birds suddenly deciding to form flocks and attack.It is apparently based on a real story that was turned into a novel. In the film, we get inside clues that the message is environmentalist. (Orders of fried chicken taken in the background. Love birds caged throughout. No respect for our feathered friends.)The directing, editing, and videography is solid even now. Special effects are dated, but still have a punch.I dislike the character of Melanie, who seems a rather callous human "bird" (woman) However, she gets her come uppence.Mitch, his mother, and sister are solidly played, as is his former girlfriend and townsfolk.I wish we had more of a story ending, but this does leave a creepier tone--that the ending is more or less up to us.

title: Hard to sum up what I just watched, but I liked it
content: I watched the classic Alfred Hitchcock horror film 'The Birds' a few years ago and I only remember that I enjoyed it (and the final shot in the movie). The rest of it I had completely forgotten. Now I've seen it again I can sort of see why. It's a difficult film to do justice when trying to - properly - sum it up.It would be easy to say that it's a horror film where birds start to attack humans. Yes, that's an adequate summary, but the film is so much more than that just saying it like that. The first half is primarily build-up, where a well-to-do socialite decides to follow a man she only just met to his secluded home town in order to play a practical joke on him.Maybe I'm just looking at it through '2023 eyes,' but it all just seems rather odd. I would call these actions 'stalking a stranger the woman had only just met' yet it's all presented as rather harmless and even romantic. But then again perhaps that's the point? This is a horror film after all and this could well all be part of creating a particularly unsettling atmosphere where things all feel a little bit too unreal to be true.It's not until about the halfway mark where all the family parties take a backseat when Woody Woodpecker and his hordes of mates start trying to take a piece of flesh or two out of our human protagonists. The effects do feel a little dated compared to today's standards and they haven't held up that well, but, if you believe what you read on the internet, it wasn't just overlaying footage of flying birds over the humans, but the producers actually trained birds to peck at the actors.It's hard to say whether I should recommend this film or not. I certainly enjoyed it both times I watched it. Hopefully it will stick in my head a little longer after this viewing. There's certainly elements of conventional horror in there, but it's the weird sub-plots that seem to give it whatever 'charm' as made it the classic it is.

title: Wonderful monster-movie tension.
content: In one of Hitchcock's sillier movies (not a bad thing), a perfectly mediocre screwball romance is thankfully interrupted by some angry birds. The attacks are great, Hitchcock choosing not to use music in those moments; it really feels like the original modern zombie movie. But the scariest stuff is whenever the birds are gathered together in complete stillness.

title: Im-peck-able Hitchcock
content: Incredibly scary late Hitchcock with many effective moments (especially the attack in the bedroom and at the children's party).  Excellent performances from Taylor, Hedron and Tandy prevail, but the film is flawed by a weak plot (Hedren coming all the way from San Francisco) and the film lacks a proper ending.  The murkyness surrounding the possible connection between the attacks and the lovebirds is very smart, and the film is a Hitchcock worth seeing.

title: Haven't looked at a seagull the same since
content: A small California beach town is attack by flocks of aggressive birds.This is a very strong thriller with memorable horror-suspense sequences.The plot is mostly character-driven as it follows a romance between the two main characters and the reactions of others to their potential relationship. This is pretty well done, especially how it ties into the scenes with the birds.Mitch and Melanie are entertaining characters but not written in an overly likeable way. The most interesting character is the domineering mother who's attitude towards Melanie seems to cleverly change in line with the bird attacks.The attack scenes do look dated in parts, but they are excellent when you consider when the film was released. Some hold up against modern filmmaking, such as the creepy jungle gym scenes, the final big siege on the house, and Melanie's moment of madness when she goes upstairs.Generally the filmmaking and art design is fantastically good. As always Hitchcock tells the story with cinematography and editing. Plus the costumes and use of colour is striking.There are some strong themes that Hitchcock makes clear such as nature fighting back. Imagery/sound like the caged birds, Melanie's fur coat and the fried chicken order at the diner all serve to remind you that as scary as these birds are, man is far worse.All actors give great performances, particularly Tippy Hedren and Jessica Tandy.For me it's an 8.5/10 but I round upwards.

title: A tad overrated, but still a great movie
content: Trying to get a rare bird, a woman is shown up in a prank by a stranger and tracks him to a small coastal community and try to kindle a romance only for a strange series of attacks by birds to interrupt everything, and as they start to think that the birds are attacking the community the remaining town-members fight back.This was a really good film with a lot to really like about it. The best feature is the idea of unending terror without giving the reason behind how these birds got this way. This tends to make the understanding of what happened in this movie really dependent on the viewer, and it works for the better because the audience doesn't really need to know. Birds are attacking and killing people, and instead of worrying about what is causing it the characters just need to worry about surviving. That allows for a dramatic increase in the terror since the survival matters more and can pay out to better effect. This also has an added bonus factor in that the birds that attack the humans aren't birds of prey but rather an assortment of ordinary everyday birds. That's what makes the attacks all the more frightening, as a regular bird seen every day instills more terror than those that aren't interacting with them on a daily basis. It gives off a realistic vibe, making the randomness of the events that much more horrific. That the big reason for the film's success lies in its superb attacks aren't all that odd either. Most notable is the entire diner sequence, where a long conversation about the impossibility of the event is broken when they start unleashing their assault. There's the scene inside a phone booth where the film traps us within the confines of the booth whilst birds ram the glass to try and break in. It's a long, drawn-out scene with a lot more action than normal for such a scene, as it plays out in spectacular fashion and gets a lot of time to do so. Another attack that really works is the one on the school children, as every new shot of them climbing the frame outside has a few more birds waiting until the camera takes you outside to see that it's completely covered in birds. When they decide to take flight, the sheer amount of birds is simply awe-inspiring, and the relentless, remorseless attack is brutal and bloody, making that it's about school-children even more frightening as them pecking and scratching is seen here delivering the shock required. The single best, though, is the final assault in the climax that starts the best possible way, where a single, weird coincidence gradually grows by each encounter and helps make this a spectacular entry. This really doesn't have a whole lot, but there are a few problems. The biggest one is the general pacing, which is rather off. The romantic subplot takes up the first fifty minutes before any sort of prolonged attack occurs, leaving the first half really slow-going. That it also contains numerous scenes of talking that leads nowhere also takes up a lot of time. The most obvious ones, where the two girls discuss past dating history, and the girlfriend and mother discuss what happened before they even knew each other are just prime examples. The answers and topics aren't brought up again, and while cementing the relationships, they drag the film out needlessly. At the very least, they could've been trimmed substantially and still kept their overall intent intact. There are also some problems with the special effects, which are, for the most part, pretty bad. The live birds do fine but are inserted into the scenes so haphazardly that it's so obvious it's a special effect that it takes you out of the scene. There are numerous shots too many to mention where the birds don't come off anywhere near realistically, even if the action itself is spectacular. These hamper the film the most and are its main weaknesses.Today's Rating/PG-13: Violence and children-in-danger.

title: Tenser Than You Think
content: One of the rare animal horror movies done right with an excellent escalation of terror with how much the birds overwhelm this small seaside town for unknown reasons other than the vague retribution of mother nature. The effects start off bad, but quickly grow really impressive with the mix of real birds in impressively large numbers and plenty of stock footage overlap effects. The first third of the movie is admittedly pretty corny as the "that just means he likes you when he insults you" and sex-negative-shaming romantic melodrama shtick gets old fast. But the rest of the character building in this small seaside town is very endearing with all of the townsfolk interacting with Tippi Hendren's character. The character herself is played quite well, as well as the chill schoolteacher and the rest of the smarmy lawyer's family. The bird attack scenes are all great and surprisingly pretty gruesome at times like with the final home invasion and especially in the attic. The schoolyard crow attack is iconic and the café debate was very entertaining. The final looming shot of the calm pile of birds eerily waiting for the main heroes to leave was an effectively chilling way to end the movie on a cautiously bright ending with a heavy reminder of what they narrowly just escaped. Alfred Hitchcock's mistreatment of lead actress Tippi Hendren is greatly disappointing, with his mistrust and endangerment of her with her fear of birds was very reckless and his sexual harassment of her being outright despicable. But as the movie stands on its own, it's quite remarkable and groundbreaking for the animal horror genre. Definitely worth a watch!

title: Cinema Omnivore - The Birds 7.9/10
content: "The world cannot be too good to such a female knockout, at least not in a '60s Hitchcock movie, Marion Crane (Janet Leigh) must perish for her avaricious caprice in PSYCHO (1960), and here, Melanie is punished for her irrational infatuation by pecking beaks of gulls and crows. It is a trifle unsavory to let Hitchcock's thinly veiled misogyny and sadism slip through our mind unscathed, inter alia, Melanie's climatic visit to the room upstairs of a battened-down house assaulted by clouds of birds is irrefutably non-sensical and misbegotten, taking the shine off the technical virtuosity that emulates the iconic shower scenes in PSYCHO, the same frenetic montage-splicing artifice works fine, but one also wonders why not let our hero the straight-arrow Mitch Brenner (Taylor) take the shaft for a change? That's the problem of a patriarchal industry borne out here."read my full review on my blog: cinema omnivore, thanks

title: FREUD explains HITCHCOCK !!
content: Another alfred Hitchcock classic that deals with ... family relationship from mother to child, jealousy and passion, all very well orchestrated by the master of suspense , even the oedipus complex in the film, by zigmund Freud, is mentioned for those who like psychoanalysis is a full plate.Melanie Daniels ( Tippie Hedren ) mysterious, socialight, very charismatic we end up wanting to discover her personality at the same time, we twist all the time for her, who ends up being enchanted by Mitch's charm ( Rod Taylor ) successful lawyer who spends his weekends in a small town called Bodega Bay , which melanie goes to her to really know mitch taking two parakeets.Hitchcock divides the film into two stages, the first the beautiful construction of the characters, their characteristics and mysteries, and when we are well "attached" to them , intrigued only by mitch's affective relationships ( passion for melanie, a feeling of friendship from his ex, the bodega bay teacher, his protective mother , obsessive and jealous and even his little sister who needs protection. In the second, the attacks of the birds begin, with great scenes always experiencing a lot of tension. It is worth remembering that we are talking about Hitchcock, taken as that of the seated protagonist, waiting to speak with the school teacher, and the playground in its background gradually increasing the number of birds without it noticing, only the public noticing, without the sound of birds, without music and just with the sound of the children's singing class it is sensational . We even remember that in this film there is no soundtrack but we have a lot of bird sound during the attacks.In addition to being fully connected to the film, we have a very subjective ending for each viewer, each one can see the answer for the entire film of " why did birds attack ?" In a different way. But you can be sure that it is not just the reaction of the bad bird feed mentioned at the beginning of the film, as they ended up carrying out attacks in another nearby city, or the relationship with the mitch sister caged parakeets, Cathy ? Or Melanie struggling stunned to regain consciousness after being attacked and visualizing Cathy? But we can be sure that when the relationship between mother-in-law and daughter-in-law is fully defined and birds are accepted, they calm down. Magnificent!

title: Strong acting, a memorable location and good pacing.
content: A classic horror which starts off as a drama/romance featuring an obsessive woman and a possessive mother but as the birds begin to behave oddly, the tension slowly builds. This is later replaced by a growing suspense and dread which doesn't let up until the rather abrupt ending. The way they managed to create something disturbing from the mundane is very effective, especially when there's little you can do to stop it. Some of the special effects are (laughably) bad due to their age but others are still just as effective and the sound the birds make as they surround the house is truly terrifying.

title: Runtime Error
content: Having just screened the movie I feel the need to warn future viewers that it is 2:21:54 long not 120 minutes! I see the movie listed everywhere citing 119 or 120 minutes but I just ran it... 2:22 from the trolley car to the end credit.My audience was my wife and 20 y.o. son neither of which had ever seen it. Both were appropriately uneasy during the movie and both felt unsettled when it was over. Score: Hitchcock 1, Time 0

title: It's a classic ror a reason
content: This movie is a classic for a reason. It centers around birds turning rogue and attacking a small coastal town, which is both bizarre and super entertaining. The suspense builds so slowly at first, and then BAM-you find yourself on the edge of your seat as flocks of birds wreak havoc! The performances, especially by Tippi Hedren, are great and really draw you into the madness. The special effects for the time are impressive, and it's fascinating how Hitchcock creates tension using sound and visuals. It definitely keeps you guessing about what these feathered fiends are up to! That said, it does have some slow moments, and the way people react to the bird attacks is hilariously over-the-top at times. But if you're in the mood for some vintage horror with a unique twist, it's a must-see. I'd give it a solid 8/10-it's a bit quirky, but that just adds to its charm! Perfect for a movie night if you want something a little different!

title: major goof that should have been caught in Dailies!
content: At Cathy's birthday party, when Mitch and Melanie climb the small hilltop to chat;you can see the Brenner Dock without any water around it and dry ground a good 100yds or more away from the dock. How in one day could that much water disappear when the day before Melanie brings the rented rowboat right up to the dock to deliver Cathy's love birds and the water level is close to the height of the Dock.Unless a major sink hole opened up during the night and swallowed probably mega tons of water its highly unlikely you would have that much water disappear.I'm surprised that a perfectionist like Hitch wouldn't of caught that and did some background reshooting...Still a great movie...s.m.

title: The Birds Deliver
content: A highly unique film for its time (and still is), Hitchcock's The Birds is great fun. I've seen it several times now and it definitely holds up well. A lot has been made of Hedren's performance with many critics saying she plays it too cool and detached. I disagree and counter that her performance is a wise and effective contrast to Suzanne Pleshette's (excellent) performance. Rod Taylor and Jessica Tandy are also both quite good. There are real moments of tension and suspense here and like most of Hitchcock's films from this period, it just overall looks great. If you haven't yet seen The Birds you really need to AND if it's ever showing on the big screen near you it's worth seeing it in that format.

title: Rod Taylor at his finest
content: The underrated Rod Taylor in his prime at his finest!

title: Caw Caw
content: It's been a while since I've been to Bodega Bay, but Hitchcock has been a favourite since I first watched a VHS of this some 30 years ago. Today I'm introducing my daughter to Alfred's avian nightmare. Now if I'm really really honest, The Birds is pretty cheesy. Hammy acting, the lovebirds swaying in the car footwell, not to mention the retro 60s charm of matte effects, but I love The Birds. Even knowing everything that happens before it graces the screen, the tension is gripping and my young companion gasps accordingly. In 60 years on The Birds hasn't lost its magic. Melanie Daniels proving that the rich have a lot of time on their hands, to go flirting with Mitch Brenner in the outskirts of San Francisco. The old fashioned bayside town is really the star for me, even more than the birds themselves and the cast of backwater characters and their simple lives acts as the perfect canvas for something so unexpected as human hunting airborne marauders. We get a "whoa" as the children sing in the school house as the birds amass and I'm taken back to my teenage self watching in awe as each scene painstakingly builds. Yes it's schlocky, yes Tippi Hedren is a bit wooden and yes it's essentially a single premise slowly drawn out over two hours, but this is one of my favourite Hitch outings and I can't wait to relive more.

title: Extraordinary Film
content: Alfred Hitchcock didn't waste any time; he started the story right from the first scene. The film is about birds, and the director included at least one bird in almost every scene. The technical side of the movie was great. Today, we could easily make a similar movie, but this one was released in 1963, when there weren't many visual effects. Still, the director and crew managed to do almost everything practically.The movie has 30 to 45 minutes of setup time, but that part is interesting and not boring. As the movie goes on, it keeps getting better. The actors did a great job, and the film was shot beautifully, even with some difficult scenes. Personally, I really like this movie; it's a must-watch for everyone. There are no sexual scenes, so you can enjoy it with your family.

title: Birds of Prey
content: Alfred Hitchcock's 'The Birds' is among the first 'predators-hunting/killing-in-packs' thriller. While there have been almost countless followers that tried to ape the effect of Hitchcock's film, hardly any of them come even remotely close to 'The Birds'. It stands on its own and even after decades, it manages to remain just as engaging, intense and chilling as the first time I saw it as child.The movie more or less starts off as a romantic comedy. The interaction between Tippi's Melanie and Rod's Mitch is amusing to watch. I found this an appealing approach to introduce the characters and their personalities without any distraction. Once Melanie is attacked by a seagull tension gradually builds both between the characters (for example when Melanie meets Rod's family) and then within the town as the birds attack.The special effects and art direction are brilliant. Music is effectively used. The screeching and pecking sounds of the birds is haunting. Tippi Hedren and Rod Taylor have great chemistry. I liked that they didn't play the cliché hero and heroine that was so apparent in films of that time. Veronica Cartwright, Jessica Tandy and Suzanne Pleshette are superb in their roles.Hitchcock's 'The Birds' is a chilling and creepy little film, one of the best of it's kind. While the bird attack sequences are tastefully shot, it is the fantastic end sequence that sends a chill down the spine.
