title: Why is this movie a classic!
content: I saw this movie a while back on cable and sat down to watch it mainly because I had always heard what a great movie it was.  YEAH RIGHT.  It was boring, it made no sense, and was their really a character that was really likeable, no.  Unless your a total hitchcock fan avoid this boring flick.

title: Just about perfect
content: This movie is just about perfect:   romance, mystery, horror, suspense. Rod Taylor is visually appealing (i.e. a hunk) but then again, I'm a little biased, since he is my favorite actor, and appears in two of my favorite films of all time (the other is the 1960 version of The Time Machine).This is one of those films that merits watching over and over for the little details alone.

title: So what?
content: Not that this film is bad by any means.But, Hitch's promos for it were far more entertaining.The question always pops into my mind about "The Birds"..."Who cares?"End of world movie? There are better ones, especially down the pike one year later in '64.Freudian in meaning? How cliché. Freud wasn't even wrong.Different? Sure.But, who cares? Fun to watch. Not much meaning apparent to gain from.What one gathers from this movie depends on who that one is.But, I'm not one of them.If I will allow myself to go nuts watching a film, gimme "Vertigo". Now, that is insanity worth 100 times the price of admission."The Birds" is a nice, scary chiller where meaning means nothing. And nothing else.

title: History isnt kind to a film's special effects
content: Histroy hasn't been especially kind to this film with regards to the outdated special effects but look beyond that for a brief second and one can truly see the horror that is apprent in this film.Basically put, I dont know how to describe Hitchcock's films.Psycho was terrifying......but why......I cant really say.  A lot of it was to do with its cinematography and its being shot in black and white, but one of the things that made The Birds such a surreal horrer film was what it lacked ........a musical score.I never thought I could be scared of the gradual build up of a bunch of ravens on a childrens playground set, but the way Hitchcock shows it is nothing short of genius.   The scene of the man in his house with his eyes pecked out also works well as a prelude for things to come

title: When birds attack...
content: Sure, I have watched the 1963 Alfred Hitchcock movie "The Birds" once or twice before, during my youth. And as I had the opportunity to sit down and watch it again in 2022, of course I did so.Now, while this movie is deemed a classic, I have to admit that I actually found the storyline to be somewhat trivial and slow paced. There wasn't really a whole lot of excitement and thrills throughout the course of "The Birds".Sure, I can imagine that this movie would have been rather thrilling back in 1963. But sitting down and watching it in 2022, then writer Evan Hunter and director Alfred Hitchcock's movie just haven't withstood the passage of time all that well."The Birds" is a watchable movie, by all means, but there simply just wasn't enough excitement throughout the nearly two hours that the movie ran for. And that makes "The Birds" a somewhat acquired taste of a movie. A classic to some, merely watchable to others, and I am somewhere in between.It wasn't that "The Birds" is a lousy or bad movie, not at all. I just didn't get that much of a kick out of watching it again here in 2022. Funny how I remember the movie as being way more entertaining and scary back from my youth.However, it should be noted that the acting performances in "The Birds" are quite good, and while the narrative is rather slow paced, then the acting performances do salvage the movie and lifts it up and carries it a great long way.The special effects in "The Birds" haven't aged well, and they are quite antiquated. Again, this was great and spectacular back in 1963, of that I am more than sure, but in 2022 not so much."The Birds" is a noteworthy movie, by all means, don't get me wrong. It just somewhat fell short of being all that entertaining for my personal preference of entertainment.My rating of "The Birds" lands on a five out of ten stars.

title: mother and son theme
content: The theme that is immediately recognized within the film is the mother and son relationship.  The mother in the film, Lydia Brenner is extremely overbearing and needy of her son, Mitch.  Lydia continually points to the fact that she needs Mitch in order to survive.  Lydia becomes especially angered as Melanie shows for dinner and Mitch show a true liking for her. In the scene after Lydia finds her friend's eyes poked out and dead from the birds attack Melanie comes in with tea.  During this scene Lydia makes it a point to explain to Melanie why she does not like her and it is strictly because Lydia does not want her son ever to leave her because she will be alone.  Lydia views Melanie as a threat, which is completely ridiculous! The theme is apparent again when Melanie encounters Annie Hayworth.  Annie is obviously still upset by her and Mitch's berak-up and reveals to Melanie the evil tendecies Lydia has. As Annie explains to Melanie that Lydia does not like anyone that is with Mitch, Melanie and the viewers get a cold and frightening feeling about Lydia and what her motives may be.  Overall, the birds attacking can connect to this overbearing mother Mrs.Brenner and her obsessive attachment to her son. The birds do begin attacking when Melanie arrives and the first person attacked is Melanie. As attacks continue Melanie is always present besides for one occasion. The attacks can be seen as an attack on anything that attacks Mitch. I think the attacks maybe a symbol of lose of control. Lydia maybe losing control of her relationship with her son Mitch because Melanie has entered his life. Therefore, it can be possible that the birds began attacking as Melanie arrived because she is the reason behind this idea of lose of control. Overall, I was pretty disappointed in the film. I thought the mother and son relationship was pretty interesting to watch and evaluate,but the film was extremely slow and lengthy. There was not enough suspense built up for the birds attacks and too much unnecessary dialogue. The special effects were pretty decent considering the time. The movie was too drawn out and did not have enough suspense and build up to hold interest for two hours!

title: My impressions after the last view
content: I find the movie absolutely great. It`s one of the masterpieces of the history of the cinema. What I`d like to say-and to know- is that after having seen the movie yesterday I`ve asked to myself if the house of our characters is a metaphor of the bird`s cage, and if the movie is about a kind of revenge of the birds against the man. About the ending, I`ve had different opinions with my friends because for me the dawn towards which the car goes means that the threat has finished and the birds are "satisfied" (for the moment!). bye to everybody

title: The Birds is A Predictable and Pointless Flight 🐦
content: I was really not a fan of this film. I found the concept quite redundant and there was no explanation as to why the birds went haywire and started attacking people. The shark in "Jaws" doesn't have a reason to attack either, but at least it's more palatable with great character moments and scenes. If this was supposed to be a commentary on how humans mistreat animals, I think it was poorly executed by Hitchcock. I much prefer "Psycho" and "Rope" over this concept over substance movie. Also these characters were as bland as sugarless lemonade, which is not the fault of the actors. The real problem is the script is poor. I think I'm leaning towards agreeing with Tarantino's opinion that Hitchcock may very well be one of the most overrated directors in film history (partially due to the restrictive Hollywood system of the time). I appreciate the look of the film, but that is not enough to carry it through all its flaws. This bird has two broken wings 🦅.

title: Grow up and think!
content: As per usual when confronted with a really challenging movie most viewers are lost.Pay attention I say.One wonders what was Hitch's intent? More than likely it was to make an open ended movie that one can interpret multiple ways. There is no explanation of why the Birds are attacking and the ending leaves no clues as to whether they will continue to attack.The Birds becomes more interesting everyday foreshadowing the environmental consciousness and animal rights consciousness. Revolutionary at that time.There are no human hero's here. Almost every character has glaring flaws, petulance, jealousy, callousness, egotistical, lust. Melanie is a rich spoiled brat, Mitch is a lawyer who has lust for Melanie and is not very nice to her at the start, Annie is jealous, and Mitches mother is weak and clinging. The Bar scene is especially delicious, every one who speaks is a jerk, from a self important "expert" ornithologist to a drunken bible thumper. Hitchcock, of course, was a master at exposing flaws in human psychology.Metaphors fly right from the start, as the protagonist human brings caged love birds ostensibly as a present but really to buy into a sexual relationship.We hear a lot about how good the shots were and the special effects, and they are good especially for the time. But the true story is really how Hitch was able to get us to watch a film with no ending.Like most truly great film this film presents plenty of questions but gives no answers. That's what's what is really interesting about this film. You don't just sit there and get entertainment spoon fed to you like a baby, you have to interact with the film.That's what most people don't get. Art is about questions not answers.

title: The Scariest "Hitchcock" I've Ever Seen (I Haven't Seen Psycho)
content: Birds fighting mankind seems unlikely, but Hitchcock makes it happen. I am not a horror fan, but 2 hour The Birds made me forget all that and I enjoyed the suspense, thrill, and horror. This is Alfred Hitchcock's best in my opinion. However, the only movies he's directed that I've seen are Rear Window, Dial M for Murder, The Birds, Rope, Marnie, Vertigo, and The Man Who Knew Too Much. This movie brought much fear to me and I wish that they weren't making a sequel because they will ruin the whole thing. This was smart, suspenseful, and gave me the feeling that Hitchcock could do anything. He can, too (including appear in his directed films. In this one, he appears coming out of the pet shop about a minute after the credits). I urge you who love suspense that have not seen The Birds yet to do so. You'll have the thrill of a lifetime.

title: Not your usual "Birds"
content: I just saw Alfred Hitchcocks's "The Birds" last night and it surprised me. For a movie about birds attacking a small California town, it was very suspenseful. Hitchcock handled the scenes very well, and the script was well written. I have to say though that the special effects were rather cheap, but I am sure back in 1963 they were state of the art. I thought that the scene where all of the birds attack the Brenners and Ms. Daniels was very creepy. However, I found that the ending was considerably disappointing, but other than that I cannot complain at all. It isn't up to todays standards of horror, but i found it quite enjoyable, so if you're looking for a good thriller, "The Birds" is definitely worth a look.

title: Why, indeed?
content: Why indeed? That's what everyone wants to know. Why did the birds suddenly decide to attack these people? Is there some connection to the middling soap opera we see played out over the first hour of the film and their attacks, (maybe they don't like middling soap operas?). Is it because they are fed up with all the pollution and people shooting at them all the time?  Or is it just because they can?Maybe Hitchcock just wanted to make a scary movie. He might ask you to imagine yourself in the restaurant and suddenly a bloodied man staggers in and says `The birds are attacking and we don't know why!' Now picture yourself in the same restaurant and suddenly a bloodied man staggers in and says,'The birds are attacking and we know exactly why!' Which is scarier?Perhaps a better question is why Hitch spent so much time, (more than usual in his films and more than you'll see in any other horror film), exploring the characters and their relationships, delving into motivations, attractions and resentments. Why does it matter that Jessica Tandy misses her husband because he is so strong and is now so dependent on her son that she doesn't want to share him? Why do we have to know that Suzanne Pleshette's schoolteacher is in love with Mitch and sees Melanie, (Tippi Hedren) as a rival? Why is Melanie's escapade in Rome or her raising funds for orphans so important? Why should we care about this? Do the birds care about these things?I think it's hopeless to try to make some connection between the `plot' and the events in the story. Hitchcock loved to experiment with the cinema and there is little sentiment and only superficial romance in most of this films. This story never gets to the point of being sentimental or romantic anyway. The film is surely not about ecology. Nobody says anything about the birds being angry about the environment or anything else.I think Hitch just liked the idea of a movie starting out to be about one thing and then turning out to be about something else entirely. That's what he did with PSYCHO, which starts out to be a crime melodrama about Janet Leigh trying to get away with some illicit funds and very suddenly becomes the ultimate `slasher' flick about Anthony Perkins and his crazy mother. Here we see a romantic comedy turn gradually into a soap opera and then gradually into a monster movie, with the birds being the monsters. The major difference is the gradual nature of the transition. The attic scene is this film's equivalent of the shower scene in PSYCHO but it doesn't have the same impact because the attacks have already begun, (and Tippi survives). The gradual pace of change is obviously intended to produce a sense of dread, rather than surprise.Looking at Tippi Hedren's performance it's hard to see why she didn't become a major star. She's gorgeous, (much better looking than her daughter, ironically named Melanie, thanks to a softer jaw line), has a strong voice, an expressive face and shows real acting ability. She should have won some kind of award for her perseverance in the attic scene, which took four days with live birds to shoot. That she came out of this an animal lover is amazing.What does it all mean? It means you got your money's worth when you bought your ticket.

title: Dull as a Gull
content: The films premise is promising and haunting as it exploits the creepy but familiar nature of birds, an animal that is universally known by humans. Unfortunately this premise is tucked away a quarter into the film. Before an birds attack there is the most unbelievable and forced romantic premise. Plot contrivences and bizarre character motivations. They provide room to allow for character growth but the beginnings is jarring.The actor is not good, especially the wooden female protagonist. I've never had a bird attack but just witnessing it is traumatizing. The movie doesn't take it seriously and worst of all the wooden performance exasperats it. The simple solution utilised at the end was available throughout the film. Especially when the attacks have escalated and the cause is alien, akin to supernatural.What I will say is the shoots of the multitude of birds are great. Marvelous and spectacular and what I sense was the intended feeling Hitchcock wanted to evoke throughout the movie. Unfortunately the movie is silent unless there is the annoyance of bird sounds which quickly turn the evoked fear and distress into frustration and distraction. All the bird attack scenes are distractingly unconvincing. I can't tell the real birds from the fake birds. The shots are dizzying. The attacks are soft for the most part until they aren't but I have already been dulled by the toothless birds. So many times are people unharmed, untouched for the most part that the graphic attacks, although frightening and effective, are few and far between.This is a precursor to masterpieces such as Jaws but on its own it is hindered by the technology, the lack of or uncreative depiction of violent, brutal, graphic attacks, and doesn't utilises Hitchcock's greatest weapon in his arsenal, the suspenseful score he is known for. Not every movie needs its first quarter to be taken up by an unnecessary and irrational subplot.

title: A showcase of Hitchcock's mastered technique
content: 3/4The Birds is the subject of an age-old debate that cinephiles often engage in: is The Birds a good or an overrated film? I am one of a neutral party that agrees with both. To me, The Birds is everything that it promised to be, nothing more.There is no debating this: it's not Hitchcock's masterpiece. The plot is this: A woman works a pet shop, she gets an order for love birds, she travels to a coastal town to get the love birds...Birds go wild and ravage the place while she falls in love with the town hunk. Why do these birds go mad? This is one of the many questions the movie will not answer. If you care enough to analyze it, be my guest. This movie does not challenge you to find answers, as it works perfectly fine if you suspend your disbelief.However, the plot is not where the movie earns its merits at all. The film is very surreal, intense, and mildly frightening as Hitch's signature spice. If anything is to be said about this movie at all, the way Hitch shot the Birds was flawless as far as camera work. The way he captured their spirit of destruction through the rule of thirds is truly cinematography in Hitchcock tradition. To me, his portrayal and control of the Birds is what makes the film.The cast (especially Tippi Hedren) are very vibrant characters full of life and genuine emotion. He was able to convey these characters without the use of a musical score was very adept, although it should not go unnoticed that in the school scene the children sing a rhyme to build up suspense. Every component compliments one another in The Birds. There is truly no wasted talent.In conclusion, I find The Birds to be a good movie. Most of all, I find it to be an important milestone in cinematic history simply for the way the birds were captured on-screen. This does not have my vote for Hitchcock's best, or even his second or third best, but it's great for what it is: a landmark movie and a fun thriller.

title: AFLAC!!!!
content: Hello fellow movie buffs!After repeated urgings from my brother, I relented and rented "The Birds". What a stinker! The only thing missing was Jessica Fletcher. I tried to allow for the fact that SFX technology was not quite as advanced back in 1963 but that didn't work for me. It's still awful. Wooden performances and a lousy production. Ugh!Just my opinion, of course.

title: Not bad but not great
content: I suggest watching "Strangers on a Train" instead. The birds was very scary, many of the techniques used in The Birds are still being used today. I would recommend it, but the ending was terrible, you would expect some sort of satisfaction, but there is none so don't get your hopes up. Notice that there is no music whatsoever in the film, adding to the frightfulness.

title: Don't watch this!!!!!!!!!!!!!!
content: This a not very scary film. For a start birds would not be so aggressive if unprovocked and it did not explain why the birds were so aggressive! I waited until the end to see what the ending was like. What ending? This is a film with no ending and if you have seen the Italian job you know what I'm talking about. If you want to see a good thriller/ horror see Children of the corn (1984) or one like this only better see Arachnophobia (1990). I'll be kind with marking 3 out of 10.

title: Doesn't work anymore
content: I saw this movie last night during a midnight screening at the student theater. After all the wonderful things I had heard about it (Hitchcock's best!), I was extremely disappointed. This movie did not age well at all.The story involves a capricious woman who apparently has played practical jokes following a man to Bodega Bay to deliver some lovebirds. We are not completely sure as to how or why they know each other, but we do know that there is a mutual attraction. Due to some strange attacks by birds, she stays with the man, the young sister, and the elderly, bizarre mother. The attacks become progressively worse, and we watch how they cope with it.Not only are the special effects horrible, the acting was a completely different style as well. Many times the camera would focus on a character doing their best to put on an "intense" face. Throughout the movie, the whole audience was laughing almost hysterically. I can't recall a time when I laughed more in a movie theater. Not to mention the awkward laughter that came after the movie ended when people thought the reel had broken, or something along that line to explain the odd ending.Obviously there were some elements that illustrate why some regard it as excellent. The fact that Hitchcock could create suspense with no score is mind-blowing. I am a huge Hitchcock fan, but I don't know if I would ever recommend this.Bottom line - this movie does not translate well.

title: My cat got scared!
content: While watching this film, my cat heard the bird noises and became slightly nervous! It's still a good horror film but Tippi looks unrealistically perfect, even after being attacked by violent birds. There's no outside help. No one comes to kill the birds or rescue the people in this small town, even though they're near San Francisco. Was Hitchcock blaming Tippi, the outsider who had romantic designs on Rod Taylor, for the bird attack? Was she too sexy for her own good? I think that's the "moral" of this story but I'm not completely sure! And yes, Jessica Tandy looks and sounds exactly like an older version of Tippi, although this is never mentioned in the movie. It's a good film although outdated, and the bird attacks are still gruesome. What I didn't like was seeing children being attacked by birds. That was in bad taste.

title: THE BIRDS
content: One of the most famous movie from director Alfred Hitchcock, but strangely not the typical feature from him. Because this is not a crime thriller suspense. Just a thriller horror suspense, where every shot, every camera angle is calculated in a so accurate, meticulous way. This is a pure masterpiece which everyone should see at least once in his or her life. It may traumatize you if you are a child; it did, concerning me. I was damn shocked, more than PSYCHO, which I also saw in the same period. But it's not the same kind of terror, same kind of horror. It is riveting, guts grabbing, very inventive, gritty, bloody but so terrific. A milestone in movie history.

title: Not as suspenseful as I imagined
content: This film is okay. Not very special like Hitchcock's "Psycho" but not as bad as many other modern horror-films. The effects with the birds are pretty good but I don't really think that birds can scare you as much as a shark can do, like in Spielberg's "Jaws" for example, which was much better I think. If Hitchcock would have done a movie like this with other animals it would have been better! I rate it 6 out to 10.

title: Not quite a masterpiece...
content: The Birds isn't a great film at all - the idea is great, and so is the script, but the direction is sssslllloooowwww, and the first hour or so is tedious. The scenes with the bird attacks are very good, and the ominous precence of the birds sitting on the school climbing frame is unforgettable. But the characters are dull, and the film doesn't get exciting at all. The problem is, today's audiences are brought up on films that eschew subtle suspense for sudden shocks and gore, and can't even feel the uncomfortable atmosphere of this film and, believe it or not, Psycho as well. Which is an awful shame.But I love films that feel they don't have to explain themselves - who says films should make complete sense? It is an art form, after all - and this gives no reason whatsoever for the events taking place, leaving the audience to guess what is going on....the awesome and chilling idea behind this movie is more effective than the actual film itself, though, so I'm going to remake this film sometime.

title: Will the kids EVER stop singing?
content: Watch this suspenseful movie and you'll understand exactly what I mean.This movie actually had me edgy after I saw it.  It is one thing to watch birds attack and know why.  It is a whole other thing to watch birds attack and have absolutely no reason.The suspense of this movie makes it exceptional.I found a few things distracting.  The blonde (Melanie) didn't bring any bags with her to Bodega Bay yet for at least three (3) days, her hair was perfect, her makeup was perfect, and her same outfit looked perfect.  She was so perfect that she was distracting.  In fact, even the blondeness of her hair was distracting.Another distracting aspect was the likeness of the mother and Melanie.  I kept thinking they were played by the same person only age makeup was being used.Aside from the distracting aspects of the film, it is very good.

title: Short Story-One Thing; Film-Another.
content: Historically, short stories/novels converted into films tend to lack some substance, naturally. While many conversions simply exclude elements of the original writing, The Birds practically disregards the original short story. The short story premise has mystery, suspense, and terror excluding the campy Mitch-Mother-Ms. Daniels triangle. The movie simply misses the valuable factors presented in the short story. For a true feeling of terror and helplessness the short story should have been the premise for the film.

title: Directorial skill, rather than acting strength.
content: Hitchcock has taken the fantastical idea from Du Maurier's book and created a film that I judge more on the skill of the director than of the strength of its cast. The portrayal of the birds as vicious, unpredictable, killers is extremely effective and frightening. The cast are methodical, all that is required for this film. Viewers may have a tiny amount of interest in the romantic sub-plot, but what really hooked me was the suspenseful imagery that Hitchcock uses: Crows on climbing frame, or crows on a telegraph line. The ruthless attacks on the children are gripping and shocking, however I would point to the scene that depicts the besiegement of the house from within as the high point of the film: No birds are to be seen but are instead represented by a pulsating crowing reverberating through the house as the desperate situation of its occupants intensifies. A classic piece of film-making.

title: One of Hitchcock's Best
content: There are so many wonderful Hitchcock elements within this movie.  The silent scenes in which tension is built and a story told with almost no dialogue or explanatory sounds, the slow building of suspense mixed with misdirection and bewildering amounts of detail in the story, the supporting town characters that are all too real in their attitudes and actions, the then state-of-the-art special effects of the birds themselves, and the excellent point-of-view camera work all add up to a great movie that does not rely just on the gore of the victims to keep the audience engaged.The Birds is best watched and taken at its face value without trying to find symbolism or meaning in what is presented.  I think that is what Hitchcock intended.  The terror is that the birds are attacking for no apparent reason - and no reason is hypothesized in the movie.  It simply is happening.  The characters have to adapt to the situation and try to stay alive.Tippi Hedren's character of Melanie Daniels is all too typical of a type of rich, sophisticated woman of the late fifties and early sixties who lived off of Daddy's money and had no real purpose for her own life.  I knew women like her.The problem with the movie comes from all of the main characters having too much emotional and historical baggage carried with them that for some unknown reason has to be exposed and discussed.  These elements add nothing to the movie and drag down the pace of the story with long scenes of dialogue during which the characters talk about past romances, insecurities, family problems, etc. Hedren's, Tandy's, and  Pleschette's characters all are plagued with so many emotional encumbrances that at times their characters just look silly or pathetic.  Such neurotic-type problems may have been fairly common of movie characters of the sixties, or it may have been Hitchcock planting proverbial red herrings, but it gets annoying at times.  The innuendo about sex in what had to have been an attempt to make the film look more `mature' now looks childish.Ultimately, though, I still place The Birds up there with Psycho and think it remains one of the best suspense/thriller movies ever.

title: Is it really that scary ?
content: I have watched Psycho and The Birds, both Hitchcock films, the only two of his I have seen. Comparing this to Psycho, I didn't think "The Birds" was that frightening. The only part of the film which had an effect on me was at the end when Melanie is attacked in the room by lots of birds. I'm not saying "The Birds" is a poor film, it obviously isn't but it didn't have the moving impact which I expected from a Hitchcock film, especially after viewing Psycho.
